Charizard.overview: Charizard's overall solid stats, great typing, and splendid movepool allow it to perform multiple roles effectively, such as special wallbreaker and physical sweeper. Its typing and decent bulk also give it a fair amount of defensive utility, allowing it to check threats like Ribombee. However, Charizard struggles to get past many metagame staples like Gigalith, particularly if it lacks Toxic, while its Speed tier leaves it unable to check multiple threats like Sneasel and Dragon Dance Scrafty.

sets.name: Special Attacker
sets.description: Charizard makes for a great wallbreaker and offensive check to Pokemon like Ribombee, Tsareena, and Gallade. Defog allows Charizard to clear all entry hazards and is the preferred option due to Charizard's ability to force out common entry hazard setters like Palossand and Weezing. Toxic cripples switch-ins such as Lanturn and Gigalith; it also allows Charizard to pressure Jellicent and Aromatisse more effectively. Lastly, Focus Blast immediately pressures Rock-types like Regirock. Fighting-types like Hitmontop and Bulk Up Scrafty appreciate Charizard pressuring their switch-ins such as Ribombee. In exchange, they can take on Charizard's answers like Gigalith and Lanturn. Pokemon like Sandaconda and Jellicent make for good partners thanks to their ability to take on attackers that force Charizard out like Lycanroc and Basculin, respectively. On sun teams, Solar Power is an option, as it makes Charizard significantly harder to switch into. On such teams, it should forego Hurricane for Solar Beam and run Weather Ball in the fourth moveslot, and Choice Specs is an option over Heavy-Duty Boots. Charizard should also be paired with other Pokemon that take advantage of sun such as Shiftry.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Thanks to its great utility options and defensive profile, Charizard can offer teams valuable support while also checking prominent threats such as Ribombee and Choice Specs Whimsicott. With Toxic, it can more easily wear down common switch-ins in Gigalith, Regirock, and Lanturn. Mystical Fire can be used as a STAB option over Flamethrower to help Charizard take on Stored Power users, notably Mesprit, Uxie, and Claydol. The move also allows Charizard to beat Scald Jellicent alongside Toxic. Good teammates for Charizard would be Pokemon such as Perrserker and Trevenant, as they help further break down Rock- and Water-types such as Regirock and Jellicent, respectively. Pokemon like Sandaconda and Weezing also pair well with Charizard, setting entry hazards to help weaken its checks and absorbing Knock Off for it. Finally, teammates such as Quiver Dance Ribombee and Nasty Plot Mesprit appreciate Charizard crippling Gigalith with Toxic, as they have a hard time breaking through it even after a boost.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Charizard's impressive Speed and coverage allows it to outspeed common Choice Scarf users like Togedemaru and Mesprit as well as threaten its would-be switch-ins such as Gigalith after a Dragon Dance. Roost allows Charizard to switch into threats like Ribombee and Whimsicott as well as set up more easily, while Thunder Punch is Charizard's best option to hit Jellicent, having a solid chance of 2HKOing it; it also hits Archeops and opposing Charizard. Charizard's middling Attack means it can't sweep unless the opposing team is very weakened; this makes wallbreakers like Vikavolt and Trevenant very appreciated. They can both take on defensive behemoths such as Jellicent and Regirock that Charizard struggles against. Mach Punch Hitmontop can check Lycanroc; similarly, Froslass can wear down its shared checks with Charizard, like Gigalith, particularly with Spikes.

sets.name: Revenge Killer
sets.description:
Persian's uncontested Speed tier, Technician Fake Out, and solid coverage make it a decent, although weak, revenge killer. However, it suffers extreme competition in this role from Pikachu, which boasts Extreme Speed and a greater offensive presence at the expense of some Speed. Fake Out lets Persian get extra damage on the foe without punishment and stall for extra poison damage, letting it follow up with Double-Edge in order to secure KOs on targets like the Silvally formes. Fake Out can also be used to pick off heavily weakened targets that have boosted their Speed, like Fraxure, in a pinch. Knock Off removes items from bulky switch-ins that otherwise disregard anything Persian can do to them, such as Mawile, Dusclops, and Hippopotas, and provides coverage for Ghost-types like Drakloak. U-turn lets Persian keep up momentum for its team, saving it from floundering against bulky foes like Stonjourner, Mawile, and Dusclops. Hypnosis can be used over Knock Off to better cripple switch-ins like Mawile but is unreliable due to its poor accuracy and leaves Persian unable to damage Ghost-types outside of U-turn. Silk Scarf is preferred in order to boost Persian's most important attacks without further cutting into its already limited longevity. Technician is vital in order to let Fake Out deal significant damage.

Persian is a good fit for bulky offense teams utilizing Spikes, which help it gradually overwhelm its switch-ins with Spikes damage, Fake Out, and U-turn. Offensive Roselia is an effective Spiker that Persian can bring in on switchins such as Mareanie, Gourgeist, and Dubwool via U-turn to set up Spikes. Roselia can also utilize Sleep Powder to put shared checks like Mawile and Pawniard to sleep. Offensive entry hazard setters like Crustle and Pawniard help weaken foes early-game, and their hazards greatly aid Persian in its role as a revenge killer. Persian can form an effective VoltTurn core with teammates like Manectric, Raichu, and Raboot, all of which can cover Pokemon that can safely switch in on Persian such as Mawile, Stonjourner, and Pawniard. Silvally-Psychic can put offensive pressure on Fighting-types Persian struggles with, such as Throh, Falinks, and Hitmontop, while also threatening to set up and breaking down targets like Mawile to help Persian clean late-game. Mr. Rime can't switch in easily but can pressure Throh and Hitmontop, and its access to hazard control helps keep Persian from being overwhelmed by residual damage. Stacking other priority users like Pawniard and Falinks with Persian can form a powerful anti-setup core that takes pressure off Persian. Both examples also deter Defog with Defiant, making them good choices for teams utilizing Spikes.

Poliwrath.overview: Thanks to its interesting assortment of attributes, Poliwrath has a unique place in PU and can provide teams with incredibly useful role compression. On top of naturally taking on Scrafty and Aggron due to its typing and bulk, Poliwrath also checks opposing Water-types like Wishiwashi thanks to Water Absorb, which distinguishes it from Quagsire. Poliwrath's movepool is also solid, containing good offensive and defensive tools that let it function as either a powerful wallbreaker or a sturdy phazer. Beyond this, Poliwrath can potentially run other sets that make different use of its good traits, such as Choice Scarf, which mitigates its mediocre Speed tier. Despite being proficient in various areas, however, Poliwrath is not a master in any one of them. Poliwrath's meager offensive stats mean its damage output can be lackluster at times, which tends to make its defensive set even more passive. Poliwrath checks a lot of the tier, but common Pokemon like Espeon, Ribombee, and Charizard similarly threaten it. Finally, Poliwrath faces serious competition in its roles from more prevalent Pokemon. In terms of other wallbreakers, Basculin is faster and has access to priority and Flip Turn, while Jellicent can be harder to answer immediately due to Water Spout. As for defensive pivots, Lanturn and Wishiwashi more comfortably deal with Charizard and generate momentum for teams, while Scrafty can compensate for its passivity by setting up on opposing walls.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Common Water-resistant foes like Ferroseed find switching into Poliwrath difficult thanks to its powerful Close Combat. Darkest Lariat threatens Ghost-types like Jellicent, which otherwise walls Poliwrath, and Cofagrigus, which despises that the move also ignores Defense boosts. Earthquake deals more damage to Lanturn than Close Combat and also OHKOs Poison Point Qwilfish after Stealth Rock. Poison Jab is another option that hits Fairy-types like Silvally-Fairy and Aromatisse harder than any other move Poliwrath viably runs. Fire-types such as Charizard and Centiskorch are good offensive checks to Grass- and Fairy-types and can support Poliwrath by wearing down its checks with either status or coverage and, in Charizard's case, removing entry hazards. In return, Poliwrath protects them against Water-type attacks and pressures switch-ins to them like Audino and Aggron. Galarian Articuno can similarly check Grass-types on top of bringing Poliwrath in safely with U-turn punishing its switch-ins with Future Sight. In return, Poliwrath pressures special walls like Gigalith and Audino and offensively checks Pokemon like Sneasel and Glastrier.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Circle Throw prevents setup sweepers like Scrafty and Quagsire from switching in on and exploiting Poliwrath. Rest lets Poliwrath remain healthy so that it can switch into threats like Absol with more ease throughout the game, and Sleep Talk limits its passivity while it's sleeping. 96 Speed EVs allow Poliwrath to outspeed Adamant Aggron and Speed tie with Sandaconda. Spikes and Toxic Spikes become especially difficult to play around due to how disruptive Poliwrath can be, with Ferroseed and Weezing being premier users of these moves, respectively. The former offers Poliwrath safety against opposing Water-types like Lanturn and Wishiwashi, the latter keeps Grass-types like Whimsicott at bay, and both can check Fairy-types like Ribombee. As for Stealth Rock users, Gigalith is a notable example, since it also provides sand to further wear foes down and takes on Pokemon such as Charizard and Vikavolt. These entry hazard setters appreciate Poliwrath absorbing Knock Off and punishing threats like Scrafty looking to exploit them. Galarian Articuno can be devastating alongside Poliwrath thanks to Circle Throw, which may force a critical member of the opposing team to take heavy damage from or be KOed by Future Sight. In return, Poliwrath annoys Pokemon such as Alolan Sandslash and Sneasel that can switch into or revenge kill Galarian Articuno. Ghost-types such as Trevenant and Silvally-Ghost are really good at exploiting Poliwrath, which makes having teammates like Tangela that can deal with them important. Tangela also commonly runs Knock Off, which makes spreading residual damage easier for Poliwrath.

Rapidash-Galar.overview: Galarian Rapidash stands out among other Terrain sweepers in PU thanks to its unique blend of characteristics. While noticeably frailer than Uxie, its main competition, Galarian Rapidash can more comfortably set up against defensive teams because of Pastel Veil and its access to immediate recovery in Morning Sun. In addition, Galarian Rapidash's higher Speed lets it naturally outrun common threats like Charizard and Galarian Articuno, making it harder to pressure once it begins setting up. However, Galarian Rapidash often needs to boost multiple times to sweep due to its mediocre Special Attack. Galarian Rapidash's four-moveslot syndrome means that it also struggles to make full use of its good coverage, which, at times, limits its early- to mid-game effectiveness. Outside of Grassy Terrain teams, there is little to no reason to use Galarian Rapidash over other Psychic- and Fairy-types like Mesprit and Whimsicott, since they provide valuable and consistent support, have greater defensive presences, and, in the case of the former, are stronger.

sets.name: Grassy Seed Sweeper
sets.description: Mystical Fire breaks through Steel-types such as Togedemaru and Ferroseed while also annoying opposing Stored Power users like Uxie by limiting their Special Attack boosts. Dazzling Gleam is mainly useful for threatening Scrafty, which would otherwise wall Galarian Rapidash. Healing Wish is a good, if niche, utility option that gives a weakened teammate another chance to either sweep or provide support. Pastel Veil protects Galarian Rapidash from being poisoned, which allows it to freely switch in on Toxic and Toxic Spikes. This can be useful for creating additional setup opportunities, something that Galarian Rapidash greatly appreciates. Thwackey is a required teammate due to its ability to automatically set Grassy Terrain upon switching in. Thwackey can also aid Galarian Rapidash by softening up foes like Ferroseed with Knock Off, generating momentum for it with U-turn, and threatening bulky Rock-types such as Gigalith. Other Terrain sweepers are similarly important partners. Hitmonlee is particularly notable for its ability to deal with Scrafty as well as Rock- and Steel-types. Galarian Rapidash pressures many annoying walls in return, such as Weezing and Quagsire.

Magneton.overview: Because of its good offensive typing, high Special Attack, and strong STAB options, Magneton can serve as a threatening wallbreaker that pressures defensive staples like Aromatisse and Gigalith. Analytic compensates for Magneton's middling Speed tier while also making it more difficult to switch into. Magneton can effectively take advantage of this thanks to its access to Volt Switch, putting opponents on the back foot while also generating momentum for its teammates. With the combination of Sturdy and Heavy-Duty Boots, Magneton can also act as a decent revenge killer, taking pressure off of its team against threats like Charizard and Lycanroc. However, the prevalence of Pokemon such as Lanturn, Lightning Rod Togedemaru, and Galarian Stunfisk makes walling Magneton easier for a lot of teams. Magneton's average Speed also leaves it outsped by common offensive threats like Gallade and Magmortar. Finally, due to its poor bulk, Magneton often struggles to safely switch in even on resisted hits and can't make full use of the defensive benefits that come with its Steel typing.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Tri Attack provides Magneton with neutral coverage for Lanturn and Vikavolt while still hitting Ground-types like Claydol. Teleport is another option that lets Magneton pivot out against Electric-immune Pokemon like Lightning Rod Togedemaru. Alternatively, Steel Beam manages to 2HKO even Bulk Up Scrafty on the switch if Stealth Rock is up, which Flash Cannon cannot achieve. Other pivots such as Ninjask and Tsareena pair well with Magneton, since they create a momentum core and help to exert increased pressure on opposing teams. These examples also threaten nuisances like Galarian Stunfisk and offer Knock Off support, while Magneton threatens physically bulky Pokemon like Weezing. Walls like Aromatisse, Weezing, and Gigalith serve as a safety net against faster Fire-types like Charizard and Magmortar that force Magneton out. Pokemon like Sandaconda and Ribombee provide Magneton with speed control in Glare and Stun Spore, respectively, which gives it more opportunities to wallbreak by making it harder to immediately threaten out. These examples falter against Pokemon such as Trevenant, Whimsicott, and Silvally-Steel, all of which Magneton can potentially exploit.

sets.name: Revenge Killer
sets.description: Thunder Wave lets Magneton debilitate setup sweepers and wallbreakers that it can't immediately OHKO, such as Silvally-Ghost and Magmortar. Toxic can be used to gradually down wear switch-ins like Claydol and Palossand. Steel Beam is another option that always OHKOes Silvally-Fairy and +1 Ribombee. Preserving Sturdy is often easy thanks to Heavy-Duty Boots and Magneton's natural immunity to residual damage from sand, even if it needs to come in and use Volt Switch or threaten a wall like Golbat after a teammate pivots out or faints. This set fits best on offensive teams in need of both a revenge killer and a pivot. Bear in mind that Magneton doesn't need much support to function, meaning you should add it to teams that benefit from its talents rather than build around it. Magneton struggles with bulky Electric-immune Pokemon such as Lanturn, which is especially problematic given that many of its targets can easily fall back on them. As such, it appreciates having teammates like Tsareena and Whimsicott. Spikes support from Pokemon like Froslass can give Magneton an easier time revenge killing Dragon Dance Scrafty and other foes it otherwise falls short of KOing.

Haunter.overview: Haunter finds a niche as a wallbreaker that opens holes for its teammates with a unique STAB combination that benefits from the tier's lack of common resistances to Ghost-types. Unlike other Ghost-type wallbreakers such as Trevenant and Silvally-Ghost, Shadow Ball allows Haunter to bypass pseudo-Ghost-type checks like itemless Togedemaru and Weezing. This allows teammates to run item removal, which makes it more flexible than Silvally-Ghost. Furthermore, the ability to choose its item, access to a secondary STAB to break past Normal-types more easily, and consistent super effective coverage for Scrafty gives Haunter a valuable niche over Trevenant. While Haunter’s secondary STAB is less spammable, the ability to beat Fairy-types like Silvally-Fairy and Clefairy is useful. A mix of good damage output, solid Speed tier, and Sludge Bomb, which poisons switch-ins, make it a unique special attacker over the likes of Vikavolt and Ribombee. Haunter outpaces several offensive threats such as Tsareena, Mesprit, and Hitmontop. However, it is left lacking against faster threats such as Archeops and Charizard, both of which force Haunter out. It also has a Speed tie with offensive Silvally formes and Timid Galarian Articuno, which makes it inconsistent at threatening them, especially if both sides are at +1. Despite three immunities and a 4x resistance to U-turn, Haunter lacks meaningful defensive utility due to its horrendous bulk and thus only takes advantage of passive Pokemon that it resists like Aromatisse. Haunter is also switched into easily by blanket special walls such as Gigalith, Lanturn, Audino, and Togedemaru.

sets.name: Substitute + 3 Attacks
sets.description: This set capitalizes on the switches Haunter forces by setting up a Substitute, which eases prediction and negates otherwise threatening priority from Pokemon like Absol, and dissuading faster Pokemon like Charizard from coming in. Sludge Bomb is chosen over Sludge Wave due to the higher poison chance, which cripples switch-ins like Gigalith and Miltank. Disable takes advantage of Pokemon that have only one attack that can break Haunter's Substitute such as Palossand and Flamethrower Weezing, but dropping Dazzling Gleam means Haunter struggles to break past Scrafty. Life Orb gives Haunter the most power while allowing it to switch moves. Choice Specs in tandem with Trick or Energy Ball instead of Substitute is an option that increases Haunter's power, notably allowing it to OHKO Scrafty and 2HKO Togedemaru. However, it is then more easily pressured by Pokemon that can outspeed it like Charizard and more reliant on prediction to succeed. Haunter struggles against Gigalith commonly running Rock Blast, so partners with a type advantage such as Sandaconda and Tsareena, are appreciated. Sandaconda also provides entry hazard support, while Tsareena brings Haunter in on checks like Weezing and Togedemaru to wear them down. Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gallade make solid partners, as they both lure in Ghost-types like Palossand and Jellicent that Haunter can break through. In return, they check Normal- and Dark-type threats to Haunter like Audino and Absol.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: The advantage that Choice Scarf Haunter has over other sets is the ability to revenge kill various Choice Scarfers like Mesprit and Rotom, as well as various sweepers like +1 Tsareena and Adamant Sandslash in sand. Dazzling Gleam lets Haunter revenge kill fast Dark-types such as +1 Scrafty and Alolan Persian. Trick allows Haunter to cripple passive checks like Audino. Haunter is very frail, so it appreciates pivot support from the likes of Togedemaru and Archeops, which can bring Haunter in on their switch-ins like Weezing and Quagsire in order to wallbreak. Blanket special walls like Gigalith, Audino, and Lanturn can switch into Haunter multiple times during a match, so partners that can wear them down such as Ribombee and Charizard, are useful to Haunter.

Hitmonlee.overview: With Hitmonlee's strong Attack and Unburden, it can function as a great Terrain sweeper. It has solid coverage and has passable bulk to set up with after using Electric or Grassy Seed. However, outside of Terrain teams, Hitmonlee is outclassed by other Fighting-types in the tier like Scrafty or Gallade due to Hitmonlee being reliant on Unburden to make progress. While it has the ability to set up, Hitmonlee still finds itself unable to get past Pokemon like Charizard and Aromatisse if it does not have the right coverage move.

sets.name: Terrain Sweeper
sets.description: Hitmonlee is exclusively used on Terrain teams, which, in tandem with Electric Seed or Grassy Seed, help it set up with Bulk Up more easily. Close Combat is Hitmonlee's best STAB move, as it does not run the same risk to miss as High Jump Kick does. Knock Off gives Hitmonlee coverage for Pokemon like Mesprit and Silvally-Ghost, cripples Pokemon like Weezing, and hits Flying-types if Hitmonlee is not running Stone Edge. Stone Edge allows Hitmonlee to remove Flying-types such as Charizard and Scyther with ease. Alternatively, Poison Jab gives Hitmonlee coverage for Fairy-types like Aromatisse and Silvally-Fairy. Hitmonlee requires either Pincurchin or Thwackey as a partner and therefore pairs well with other Terrain sweepers like Thievul. On Electric Terrain teams, Jolteon can pressure Flying-types for Hitmonlee so it can run Poison Jab, and Nature Power Ribombee can lure Charizard if Electric Terrain is still active. For Grassy Terrain teams, Thwackey is able to wear down Pokemon like Weezing and Charizard for Hitmonlee to break through late-game.

Weezing.overview: Weezing's physical bulk, wide utility movepool, and abilities allow it to function as a great defensive pick for teams. A pure Poison typing leaves it with only two weaknesses, one of which can be negated by Levitate, and important resistances, letting it wall Pokemon that utilize Grass- and Fighting-type moves such as Tsareena and Hitmonlee. A solid Special Attack stat and the threat of status make Weezing hard to switch into as well, and the ability to lay Toxic Spikes allows it to provide support for its team and wear down its checks. However, Weezing's low special bulk means even neutral strong special hits will take a big chunk out of its health. Weezing also has unreliable recovery, especially if it forgoes Black Sludge, since its only viable option is Pain Split. A weakness to Psychic also leaves it forced out by foes such as Mesprit and Gallade, and by those with Psychic-type coverage, such as Whimsicott and Ribombee, if it is chipped enough. Choosing Neutralizing Gas also means it struggles with Ground-types such as Palossand.

sets.name: Defensive Utility
sets.description: Weezing can function as both a wall and a supporter. Will-O-Wisp cripples against Pokemon immune to poison such as Aggron and Ferroseed. Taunt can be used to shut down opposing defensive Pokemon such as Gigalith and Regirock. Flamethrower allows Weezing to threaten Steel-types and Froslass beyond a burn. Neutralizing Gas sacrifices a Ground immunity to let Weezing take advantage of Pokemon that rely heavily on their abilities, such as Gurdurr, Gigalith, and Scyther, and also lets it absorb Toxic Spikes. The given EV spread allows Weezing to outspeed Pokemon like defensive Alcremie. Weezing pairs best with specially defensive Pokemon that can absorb special hits for it; these include blanket checks to special attackers, such as Gigalith and Lanturn, which enjoy Weezing soaking up Fighting- and Grass-type moves for them. Steel-types like Aggron and Ferroseed can handle special attackers like Mesprit, Ribombee, and Galarian Articuno that can overwhelm Weezing. In return, Weezing can absorb Fighting- and, if running Levitate, Ground-type moves for them.

Rhydon.overview: Rhydon is a solid Stealth Rock user thanks to its great Eviolite-boosted bulk, fearsome Attack stat, good coverage choices, and excellent offensive typing. Its STAB EdgeQuake combination is difficult to switch into, especially when combined with coverage options like Heat Crash to deter frailer Grass-types like Gourgeist-S and Whimsicott from switching in. Rhydon's bulk and defensive typing enable it to become a decent offensive switch-in to common staples like Charizard, Gigalith, and Archeops while also being capable of threatening out Defoggers like Rotom, Articuno, and Silvally-Poison. While Rhydon has a terrific offensive typing, it is weak to numerous common attacking types, causing it to falter against certain entry hazard removers like Whimsicott and Hitmontop. Rhydon's low Special Defense, Speed, and lack of reliable recovery cause it to get worn down very quickly by entry hazards and status, making it reliant on cleric support to aid its longevity.

sets.name: Offensive Stealth Rock
sets.description: Heat Crash allows Rhydon to lure in and OHKO Ferroseed and Whimsicott as well as Gourgeist-S after Stealth Rock. Rhydon can set up with Swords Dance against passive foes like Audino, Clefairy, and Miltank, making it even more difficult to switch into. Rhydon can also run a more specially defensive set with an EV spread of 252 HP / 16 Atk / 240 SpD to switch into Ribombee and Charizard more reliably and trade against offensive teams. However, this comes at the cost of losing a lot of its offensive presence. Rhydon enjoys Grass-types like Trevenant, Gourgeist-S, and Tangela covering against its weaknesses to Water, Ground, and Grass. In return, Rhydon can switch into Fire- and Flying-type attacks aimed at them. Ferroseed pairs particularly well with Rhydon to form an entry hazard-stacking core, wearing down each other's checks, although they must be wary of their shared weakness to Fighting. Cleric support from Aromatisse and Audino can patch up Rhydon's vulnerability to getting worn down by entry hazards and status.

Tangela.overview: Tangela's solid bulk, further bolstered by Eviolite, in combination with its great ability in Regenerator makes it a great switch-in to top physical threats like Archeops, Tsareena and Trevenant. Tangela also has great supportive options such as Knock Off, Leech Seed, Toxic, and Sleep Powder, which makes up for its mediocre damage output. However, Tangela is held back by its poor special bulk and bad typing, as being pure Grass leaves it vulnerable to a plethora of top Pokemon like Ribombee, Vikavolt, and Magmortar. Additionally, Tangela is very reliant on its item Eviolite, and a lot of Pokemon that it checks carry Knock Off, making Tangela less reliable of an answer to them. Furthermore, it dislikes getting poisoned by Toxic, making it less effective as a pivot.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Knock Off is a great utility move and is able to remove items such as Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon such as Centiskorch, Charizard, and Ribombee. Leech Seed allows Tangela to cripple answers like Charizard and potentially help a teammate like Regirock, although Synthesis gives it an easier time beating Pokemon like Absol in a one-on-one, which it can't reliably do when running Leech Seed. Toxic cripples defensive Pokemon better, while Sleep Powder cripples offensive Pokemon such as Gallade and allows it to bring a wallbreaker or setup sweeper in with more ease. Rock-types such as Gigalith check Fire-types such as Magmortar and Charizard. Lanturn also checks threats like Magmortar, Charizard, and Galarian Articuno that Tangela dislikes; it can also provide Heal Bell support for Tangela. In return, Tangela checks Palossand and Sandaconda for them and can bolster their health with Leech Seed. Since Tangela hates Poison-types like Golbat and Weezing, partners like Mesprit and Vikavolt are appreciated. In return, Tangela checks Absol and Togedemaru for them. Frail wallbreakers like Magneton, Archeops, and the aforementioned Vikavolt dislike the presence of foes such as Silvally-Ground, Togedemaru, and Lycanroc, so Tangela makes for a great defensive backbone to rely on.

Kangaskhan.overview: Kangaskhan carves itself a role as a priority attacker in the PU metagame with the combination of Fake Out and Sucker Punch, enabling it to become a good blanket check against offensive teams thanks to its solid power and bulk. Scrappy allows it to combat Ghost-types like Froslass, Gourgeist-S, and especially Silvally-Ghost, distinguishing itself from other Normal-types. Kangaskhan's decent Speed tier permits it to outspeed threats like non-Choice Scarf Mesprit and Gallade, while its solid natural bulk enables it to take a hit if necessary and continue to wallbreak. However, despite Kangaskhan's good Attack stat and access to Earthquake, it struggles against Pokemon resistant to Normal-type attacks like Gigalith, Regirock, and especially Ferroseed, as it lacks enough power to muscle past them. Kangaskhan is also reliant on hazards to supplement its damage output, as it struggles to break through teams without them. While its Speed tier is acceptable, offensive threats like Silvally-Fairy, Archeops, and Charizard can outpace it and threaten it with heavy damage. Lastly, although Kangaskhan has a wide movepool, other set options, like Choice Band and defensive variants, tend to be outclassed by other Pokemon with more immediate power or better defensive profiles.

sets.name: Dual Priority
sets.description:
Fake Out enables Kangaskhan to score free chip damage and flinch offensive Pokemon like Froslass, Charizard, and Silvally-Ghost. It should be noted, however, that Ribombee cannot be flinched because of Shield Dust. Double-Edge is its primary STAB attack, dealing heavy neutral damage against Tsareena, Silvally-Fairy, and Mesprit. Earthquake OHKOes Togedemaru and Magneton while being its best option to damage Aggron, Ferroseed, and Gigalith. Sucker Punch finishes off sufficiently weakened offensive foes like Choice Scarf Rotom, Galarian Articuno, and Scyther. An Adamant nature is preferred to maximize its power and achieve KOs against Scrafty, Galarian Articuno, and Silvally formes, though a Jolly nature can be opted for to outpace Mesprit and Gallade. Silk Scarf boosts the power of its STAB moves and enables it to wallbreak as hard as possible; however, Heavy-Duty Boots can alleviate Kangaskhan's susceptibility to getting worn down by entry hazards.

Entry hazard support and chip damage from the likes of Qwilfish, Ferroseed, and Gigalith are greatly appreciated to whittle down foes like Lanturn, Weezing, and Palossand to be closer in Kangaskhan's KO ranges. Even with Earthquake to hit Gigalith and Regirock for super effective damage, Kangaskhan appreciates Water-types that effectively check them, like Wishiwashi and Jellicent, as they both threaten Kangaskhan’s checks with Scald. Physically defensive Pokemon like Tangela and Sandaconda can also switch into Rock-types and threaten them out. Ferroseed stands out as an excellent Kangaskhan answer, so Fighting-types like Gallade and Sawk are appreciated to counter it. Special wallbreakers, such as Frosmoth, Ribombee, and Rotom, are also recommended to weaken such checks and facilitate opportunities for Kangaskhan to attack. Charizard also works nicely as a partner, since Kangaskhan’s checks like Ferroseed, Gigalith, and Regirock can either be hit super effectively with Fire Blast or worn down by Toxic. In return, Kangaskhan can pressure specially defensive foes such as Clefairy, Aggron, and Togedemaru with its STAB attacks and coverage.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Mr. Mime is a great revenge killer due to its overall good Speed and Special Attack, allowing it to pick off threats such as Dubwool, Falinks, Stonjourner, and even some Silvally formes. Its access to Healing Wish allows it to bring in a weakened teammate back to full health and cure any existing status conditions, giving it more utility and team support, while Trick allows it to cripple defensive Pokemon like Type: Null and Musharna. Mr. Mime can also viably run Choice Specs to increase its wallbreaking power, though the Speed boost from Choice Scarf is normally preferred, since Mr. Mime is otherwise outsped by Silvally and Drakloak. Focus Blast or Mystical Fire can be used over a support move to allow Mr. Mime to do more damage to Steel-types like Klang and Mawile. Teleport is another option that allows Mr. Mime to provide a valuable negative-priority pivoting move and gain momentum for an offensive team.

Choice Scarf Mr. Mime itself appreciates strong wallbreakers like Life Orb Falinks, Basculin, and Silvally-Grass so that it can clean up once bulkier Pokemon like Type: Null and Mawile are weakened and faster threats like Manectric or Choice Scarf Leafeon are taken care of. These Pokemon also appreciate Mr. Mime's Healing Wish support so they can come back for a second time late-game, allowing them to be played more aggressively early in the game. Mr. Mime's generally low damage output means it also appreciates help from Spikes setters like Roselia and Crustle to wear down Pokemon it usually can't break through. Setup sweepers like Nasty Plot Gourgeist, Rock Polish Stonjourner, and Shell Smash Crustle also appreciate Mr. Mime's ability to give them a second chance at setting up to sweep with Healing Wish or shut down a defensive Pokemon like Type: Null or Pyukumuku with Trick that could keep them from sweeping. Mr. Mime also appreciates their ability to break through bulkier Pokemon like Mawile and Shiinotic for it to pick off. While Mr. Mime is decently fast, it is still outsped by Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Manectric as well as Flame Charge Silvally formes, so priority users like Hitmontop and Falinks or Speed-boosting sweepers like Rock Polish Stonjourner help take care of these threats. Defensive checks to these Pokemon like Palpitoad, Drakloak, and Pyukumuku also help Mr. Mime handle them. Alternatively, if Mr. Mime is running Trick, its ability to cripple special walls by removing their items allows other specially offensive Pokemon like Raichu and Choice Specs Glaceon to break through them better.

Scyther.overview: Scyther is a decent pivot in PU due to its decent Speed tier and high Attack. Scyther also possesses a resistance to Fighting and semi-decent bulk, granting it some defensive utility. In addition, Scyther can easily apply offensive pressure due to its Technician-boosted Dual Wingbeat and Knock Off. However, Scyther has a mediocre defensive typing with a weakness to Flying- and Rock-types, both of which are common in the tier. Scyther also has difficulty checking Fighting-types, as many of them carry either Knock Off or Stone Edge. Furthermore, Scyther has difficulty breaking through common walls even with a boost, and while it has a decent Speed tier, it is still outsped by common threats such as Archeops, Sneasel, and Ribombee. Finally, Scyther faces stiff competition from Archeops, as it provides more power to a team.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: Scyther is an excellent momentum grabber due to its offensive presence. Knock Off cripples common switch-ins such as Regirock and Weezing, making them easier to pressure. Roost is an option to extend Scyther's longevity while also taking advantage of its natural ability to force switches and passive Pokemon such as Palossand. Scyther fits nicely on VoltTurn teams due to its pivoting abilities. Lanturn works well with Scyther, as Lanturn can bring it in via a slow Volt Switch and cure its status with Heal Bell while checking Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Togedemaru that it has a hard time against. Other Volt Switch users such as Rotom and Vikavolt also pair nicely with Scyther, as they handle each other’s weaknesses while forming a VoltTurn core. Tsareena and Mesprit appreciate Scyther bringing them in via U-turn against Pokemon Scyther struggles to break through, such as Regirock and Weezing.

Articuno.overview: Articuno secures itself a niche on defensive teams as a solid Defogger with unique qualities. Its great special bulk and reliable recovery let it take on Pokemon such as Ribombee, Mesprit, and Frosmoth without much issue. Pressure + Defog can threaten entry hazard users that don't threaten Articuno, such as Druddigon and Mesprit, and it is able to stall Pokemon such as Whimsicott lacking Knock Off and Palossand due to its massive special bulk. Unfortunately, Articuno's typing gives it few relevant resistances and weaknesses to common types such as Electric, Fire and Steel as well as a 4x weakness to Rock-types. This makes Articuno reliant on Heavy-Duty Boots to avoid Stealth Rock and very vulnerable to Knock Off. Articuno often requires dedicated support to succeed and only fits on specific playstyles such as stall or semi-stall.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Freeze-Dry hits Ground-types such as Sandaconda and Rhydon as well as Water-types such as Lanturn and Jellicent. Alternatively, U-turn generates momentum for Articuno's team but cannot directly threaten the aforementioned Ground- and Water-types. Brave Bird hits Bug-types such as Ribombee and Centiskorch and prevents them from turning Articuno into setup fodder. Heal Bell can be used for cleric and frees up a slot for the most common cleric on defensive teams, Audino. Toxic is also an option to cripple switch-ins such as Gigalith and Magmortar, but it lacks the utility of either Brave Bird or Heal Bell. The given Speed EVs let Articuno outspeed neutral-natured base 65 Speed foes such as Centiskorch and Frosmoth, while the remaining EVs go into its special bulk to better check Ribombee and Galarian Articuno. Since Articuno mainly fits on stall teams, it should be paired with Knock Off absorbers such as Scrafty and Weezing; Scrafty also absorbs status, while Weezing can burn physical attackers.. In return, it provides valuable Defog support and checks Frosmoth and Centiskorch, which have good matchups against defensive teams. Other entry hazard removers such as Claydol and Tsareena can free up a moveslot for Articuno and allow it to run another utility move while also threatening entry hazard setters such as Reigrock and Gigalith. Articuno's common weaknesses can be negated by partners such as Palossand and Quagsire. Both absorb Electric- and Rock-type moves, with Palossand also providing Stealth Rock support and Quagsire taking on Fire- and Steel-type moves for Articuno.

Articuno-Galar.overview: Galarian Articuno is one of PU's best and most dangerous special attackers thanks to its high Special Attack and great offensive typing. Part of what makes Galarian Articuno so threatening is Future Sight, which can severely limit its counterplay. Furthermore, Galarian Articuno is somewhat versatile, capable of serving either as a pivot that wallbreaks for itself and its teammates or a Choice Specs user that can tear through many teams with its power and coverage. Both sets fit on similar teams, which can make it hard to predict what Galarian Articuno is going to do and play around it. Galarian Articuno even has a nice defensive presence because of its decent bulk and recovery, with its typing also providing it useful opportunities to switch in against foes like Tsareena and Mesprit. However, Galarian Articuno can only reliably come in on threats that are weak like Whimsicott or Choice-locked like Mesprit. This is because Pokemon like Weezing, Sandaconda, and Scrafty can either threaten it with status or super effective coverage. Galarian Articuno also struggles to break through bulky Rock- and Steel-types like Gigalith, Aggron, and Galarian Stunfisk, given its lack powerful coverage for them. Finally, due to its middling Speed tier, Galarian Articuno is outpaced and easily pressured by Pokemon such as Archeops and Basculin.

sets.name: Heavy-Duty Boots
sets.description: This set lets Galarian Articuno serve as an offensive pivot that checks defensive Pokemon like Weezing and Sandaconda and generates momentum for its teammates. Protect is a niche alternative to U-turn that stalls a turn after using Future Sight and allows Galarian Articuno to see what move Choice item users like Sneasel and Togedemaru will lock into. However, U-turn tends to be better, since it maximizes the pressure Future Sight puts on teams. Freezing Glare can be used over Future Sight for an accurate and immediately damaging STAB move, although it's noticeably weaker. Physical wallbreakers such as Hitmontop, Absol, and Trevenant appreciate Future Sight deterring their checks from switching into them and, in return, break through special walls like Gigalith and Articuno. Since many of Galarian Articuno's best checks are grounded, support from entry hazard setters such as Weezing, Ferroseed, and Froslass is very useful. These Pokemon have an easier time keeping their entry hazards up thanks to Galarian Articuno's Competitive discouraging Defog attempts, and the former two can also sponge hits from potential revenge killers like Archeops. Because of its weakness to Knock Off and reliance on Heavy-Duty Boots, Galarian Articuno should never be a team's only way to deal with Fighting-types. More reliable checks to them like Aromatisse, which can also eliminate status with Aromatherapy, are therefore important partners. It's worth noting that Heavy-Duty Boots Galarian Articuno can alternatively serve as a decent setup sweeper with Calm Mind, forgoing U-turn and opting for Freezing Glare instead of Future Sight. Such a set is more self-reliant, since it allows Galarian Articuno to more readily exploit the switches it forces.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Future Sight becomes incredibly strong when powered up by Choice Specs but shouldn't be used as this set's only Psychic-type STAB move. Psyshock hits special walls like Audino and Lanturn harder than Freezing Glare and more reliably than Hurricane, but Freezing Glare has better overall damage output. Shadow Ball hits Steel-types for neutral damage and threatens opposing Psychic-types such as Claydol and Mesprit more consistently than Hurricane. Entry hazard control is important, since Stealth Rock prevents Galarian Articuno from freely switching in. Tsareena and Whimsicott are notable removers, since they both threaten common entry hazard setters like Gigalith and Regirock and can use Knock Off to soften shared checks with Galarian Articuno, such as Alolan Sandslash. Tsareena can go one step further by running High Jump Kick to eliminate unsuspecting Steel-types altogether. Another good example is Charizard, which pressures Steel-types and offensively checks faster Pokemon like Ribombee. Particularly, if it lacks Toxic, Charizard also enjoys Galarian Articuno overwhelming its primary switch-in in Gigalith. Setup sweepers like Scrafty and Silvally-Fairy appreciate Galarian Articuno giving them an easier time breaking through teams and finishing them off late-game. They also find Future Sight dissuading their checks and counters from switching in very useful, since this can translate to either a forced KO or more turns to set up.

Lanturn.overview: Lanturn has unique utility as a bulky Water-type thanks to its splendid defensive typing and great ability. This allows it to check a myriad of Pokemon such as Charizard, Rotom, and Basculin. It can also act as a pivot due to Volt Switch, which allows it to serve as a damage sponge to bring stronger yet more delicate wallbreakers in such as Archeops and Scyther that benefit from specially defensive or Grass-type Pokemon being brought in. However, it struggles switching in against Ground-types, which other bulky Water-types like Jellicent are normally able to handle; Lanturn also has to rely on passive recovery due to its lack of a reliable recovery move, which makes it unreliable as a wall for longer games.

sets.name: Bulky Pivot
sets.description: Protect is used to stall out Toxic turns and safely gain passive recovery from Leftovers. Heal Bell can be used over Protect to make Lanturn a cleric to assist its teammates while also making it less vulnerable to opposing Toxic users; however, this leaves it more open to Choice item users like Whimsicott and Aggron, and faces competition from Aromatisse. The HP EVs are used to maximise Leftovers recovery, and the Defense EVs are used to allow Lanturn to tank a +1 Earthquake from Dragon Dance Charizard after Stealth Rock. The Speed EVs let Lanturn outspeed maximum Speed, neutral-natured base 40 Pokemon such as Rhydon, and the Special Attack EVs are for Lanturn to OHKO Rhydon with Scald. Defensively, Lanturn needs support from Pokemon that can take on Grass- and Ground-type threats like Whimsicott and Sandaconda. This makes Pokemon such as Charizard, Whimsicott, and Weezing solid partners. Lanturn can also support wallbreakers such as Whimsicott and Ribombee that can offensively pressure its main checks, while it supports them defensively and safely brings them in via Volt Switch.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description: Assault Vest allows Lanturn to switch into special attacking threats such as Basculin and Magmortar without sacrificing power. Hydro Pump is an option over Scald, allowing it useful rolls such as a guaranteed OHKO on offensive Charizard with an accuracy and utility tradeoff. Discharge can cripple common Pokemon like Mesprit, while Dazzling Gleam 2HKOes Bulk Up Scrafty. The Speed EVs are used for maximum Speed, neutral-natured base 50 Pokemon and lower such as Aggron and Perrserker. Pokemon like Ferroseed appreciate Lanturn being able to wall their checks like Charizard, and it is also defensively supported by Pokemon such as Palossand and Sandaconda that switch in on physical threats like Archeops and Aggron that take advantage of it.

Quagsire.overview: Quagsire is seen on stall teams and sometimes balance teams thanks to its support moves, Unaware, and reliable recovery. With Unaware, Quagsire is able to counter many setup sweepers such as Scrafty, Silvally-Ghost, Charizard, and Sandaconda. Additionally, it fulfills a lot of role compression for said teams thanks to its wonderful defensive typing providing an Electric immunity to foes like Togedemaru and Rotom and making it an excellent switch-in to Aggron. However, Quagsire's 4x weaknesses to Grass-types and Freeze-Dry leave it unable to check certain Pokemon such as mixed Silvally formes as well as Perrserker. Furthermore, Quagsire fails to halt incredibly strong wallbreakers like Life Orb Gallade and Choice Band Sawk in their tracks due to them comfortably 2HKOing it. Lastly, Quagsire has poor Special Defense, which makes it struggle against common special wallbreakers like Vikavolt, Choice Specs Mesprit, and Whimsicott.

sets.name: Unaware Wall
sets.description: Scald is essential for Quagsire, as it burns Grass-types that can switch into its STAB moves like Tsareena and Gourgeist-S. Toxic wears down switch-ins like Whimsicott, Ribombee, and Vikavolt. Curse is another option to provide stall teams with a bulky setup sweeper and beat Bulk Up Scrafty reliably. Haze is also a good option to prevent setup opportunities from foes like Ribombee and Silvally-Fairy. Heavy-Duty Boots is preferred for its ability to nullify entry hazards, since Quagsire's bulk isn't largely impressive to begin with. Taking 44 EVs from Defense and putting them in Special Defense allows Quagsire to switch into Quiver Dance Ribombee, although it makes it easier to overwhelm on the physical side. Weezing is an outstanding partner for Quagsire, as it provides a Toxic immunity and a switch-in to Grass-types like Tsareena. Audino provides cleric support and appreciates Quagsire's abilities to handle setup sweepers that take advantage of its passiveness, like Sandaconda and Scrafty. Charizard or Articuno makes for a fine Defogger to pair with Quagsire, as entry hazards can severely cripple Quagsire's longevity if it loses its Heavy-Duty Boots.

Qwilfish.overview: Qwilfish makes for a solid Spikes user in PU. Its high Speed tier differentiates itself from other Spikes users like Ferroseed and Alolan Sandslash, making it a good fit on more offensive teams. It is a decent switch-in to Fighting-types such as Hitmontop and works against Swords Dance Silvally formes in a pinch as well. Also, it is one of the few Toxic Spikes absorbers available. Qwilfish frequently gets opportunities to set Spikes against defensive Pokemon such as Audino and Aromatisse that cannot threaten it. However, Qwilfish is checked by common special attackers like Galarian Articuno and Charizard. Qwilfish also struggles against common entry hazard removers such as Rotom due to being worn down too fast.

sets.name: Spikes
sets.description: Taunt puts a stop to passive Pokemon like Ferroseed and Weezing. Waterfall prevents Qwilfish from being too passive and checks defensive Charizard and Centiskorch. Thunder Wave cripples Pokemon that fail to OHKO Qwilfish like Silvally formes and can also be useful against setup sweepers such as Scyther. Poison Jab is another option that lets Qwilfish immediately threaten Whimsicott and Ribombee. Destiny Bond is handy to grab momentum on more offensive teams, as it can remove some slower wallbreakers like Trevenant. Toxic Spikes can also be used with Substitute users like Silvally-Ghost and Frosmoth. Intimidate helps against Tsareena and Silvally formes but can be a liability against Galarian Articuno, making Poison Point a fair option. Poison Point combined with Rocky Helmet can also be rather annoying for Pokemon such as Scyther. Qwilfish pairs nicely with Ghost-types like Silvally-Ghost and Cofagrigus because they spinblock, and in return they appreciate Spikes positioning them for a sweep. Rapid Spin users like Coalossal and Hitmontop synergize well with Qwilfish to keep Qwilfish's entry hazards up. Charizard appreciates both Spikes and Thunder Wave support and threatens Pokemon like Whimsicott for Qwilfish in return. Pokemon like Quiver Dance Ribombee and Swords Dance Silvally-Ghost value Qwilfish's Spikes to sweep more easily.

Sneasel.overview: Sneasel is a strong offensive threat in PU thanks to its high Speed that allows it to outpace major threats such as Archeops and near-unresisted STAB move combination in Knock Off and Triple Axel, which are powerful enough to make up for Sneasel's lacking Attack stat. Sneasel can further improve its damage output with Swords Dance or Choice Band. However, even with these options, Sneasel can struggle to break through walls like Weezing and Aromatisse. Sneasel's bulk is very low, making it difficult to switch into even the most passive defensive Pokemon, such as Palossand. It also doesn't help that not running Heavy-Duty Boots leaves Sneasel extremely vulnerable to all forms of entry hazards, while running it leaves Sneasel somewhat weaker and more vulnerable to status. Sneasel also faces competition from other fast revenge killers such as Archeops and Whimsicott, which have more switch-in opportunities and pivoting. Nevertheless, nothing in the tier can rival Sneasel's combination of typing, Speed, and powerful STAB combination.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Due to Sneasel's weakness to Stealth Rock and susceptibility to all other entry hazards, Heavy-Duty Boots is the primary option for its held item. However, Life Orb can be used for an easier time sweeping, and Lum Berry gives Sneasel a one-time out from being crippled by status from the likes of Weezing and Jellicent. Sneasel rarely wants to directly switch into attacks, so it is best brought in as a revenge killer or through pivots such as Silvally-Fairy and Uxie. Silvally-Fairy is also able to remove hazards, while Uxie is able to set Stealth Rock up, and both can also check Fighting-types like Passimian, which can cause trouble for Sneasel. These Fighting-types, as well as defensive threats like Weezing and Silvally-Steel, should be taken out or greatly weakened for Sneasel before it starts setting up. Wallbreakers such as Charizard and Archeops are ideal for this role. Spikes setters and Rocky Helmet users such as Qwilfish and Druddigon are also ideal for dealing chip damage to Choice Scarf users such as Passimian and Togedemaru, ideally putting them into range of Sneasel's +2 Ice Shard before it starts setting up.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band gives Sneasel a good amount of raw power to spam its STAB moves. Low Kick provides coverage for various Pokemon that would take longer for Sneasel to wear down, such as Regirock and Silvally-Steel. Similarly to its Swords Dance set, Sneasel has difficulty hard switching in and is therefore best brought in as a revenge killer or through pivots such as Lanturn and defensive Mesprit. Because full control over the entry hazard game is difficult, Sneasel will either want very effective entry hazard removers or setters. Capable entry hazard removers such as Silvally-Fairy and Whimsicott give Sneasel more chances to wallbreak and are better for teams that can bring it in more frequently. Tsareena is an effective Rapid Spin user in some matchups and also a powerful wallbreaker in its own right, capable of wearing down many defensive Pokemon such as Weezing in conjuction with Sneasel. Entry hazard setters such as Ferroseed and Qwilfish make Sneasel more devastating each time it comes in but tend to also allow Stealth Rock on Sneasel's side of the field, limiting its switch-ins. Sweepers and cleaners such as Quiver Dance Ribombee and Dragon Dance Scrafty also make for good teammates, as they appreciate Sneasel's ability to deal heavy damage to opposing walls.

Piloswine.overview: Piloswine is able to set up Stealth Rock and stand out from other setters with its unique STAB combination and priority. Piloswine is able to pressure opposing Stealth Rock setters such as Druddigon and traditional ground-type checks like Whimsicott. Its typing and being able to pick off weakened Pokemon is its greatest strength. While it has a decent offensive presence, it suffers from a lack of recovery making it hard to deal with Pokemon like Vikavolt in the long run. Its typing also hinders it defensively as it leaves Piloswine vulnerable to Togedemaru, common fighting-types like Passimian, as well as Rock-types such as Archeops and Aggron that other Ground-types such as Palossand handle reliably.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description: Piloswine can be overwhelmed by Fighting-types like Sawk, so it appreciates Pokemon such as Weezing countering them and absorbing Knock Off, which limits Piloswine's defensive potential. In return, Piloswine can pivot into Volt Switch users like Galvantula. Piloswine gets quickly worn down, since it lacks any form of recovery; Aromatisse can alleviate this issue by providing cleric and Wish support and serving as a switch-in to Fighting-types and Knock Off. In return, Aromatisse benefits from Piloswine consistently switching into Arctozolt. Piloswine is able to pick off weakened Pokemon like Whimsicott and Ribombee and take some pressure off Pokemon such as Charizard to deal with them. Charizard makes for a solid partner, as it provides entry hazard removal and beats Tsareena, which Piloswine cannot handle with Ice Shard. Piloswine also has solid synergy with Silvally-Dragon, which can pivot into Water-types like Basculin and benefit from Piloswine weakening threats like Weezing and Gigalith to sweep.

Miltank.overview: Miltank's Normal typing and solid bulk allow it to reliably switch into the threatening Ghost-types of the tier, such as Froslass, Gourgeist-S, and Trevenant, depending on its ability. Thanks to a wide array of utility moves such as Stealth Rock, Heal Bell, Thunder Wave, and Milk Drink, it is able to provide important role compression while having reliable recovery. Two great defensive abilities and great mixed bulk make Miltank easily customizable to a specific team's needs, with Thick Fat letting it check Fire-types such as Charizard and Sap Sipper letting it check Grass-types such as Tsareena lacking High Jump Kick. However, Miltank can be much too passive at times, relying on Toxic and Seismic Toss to maintain pressure, which can be sorely lacking against foes such as Cofagrigus and Togedemaru. It lacks many resistances, making it easy to overwhelm with attackers such as Tsareena if lacking Sap Sipper and Centiskorch if lacking Thick Fat. It also has a very relevant Fighting weakness, leaving it unable to face the Fighting-types in the tier such as Gallade and Scrafty.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: If Stealth Rock is already taken by a teammate, then Heal Bell is a solid replacement that lets Miltank function as a cleric. Toxic is useful for crippling opposing defensive threats such as Gigalith. Seismic Toss is the chosen attacking move due to it having a consistent damage output, but Body Slam is able to spread paralysis at the cost of inconsistent damage output. Thick Fat allows Miltank to better counter Froslass and take other Fire- and Ice-type moves from Pokemon such as Charizard and Alolan Sandslash, while Sap Sipper makes Miltank the tier's only reliable switch-in to Gourgeist-S and Trevenant and deters Tsareena's Power Whip. Scrappy is an option to damage Ghost-types such as Silvally-Ghost and Haunter, which would otherwise wall Miltank, barring its status, but lacks the defensive utility of either Thick Fat or Sap Sipper. The Speed EVs allow Miltank to outspeed Jolly Scrafty and the entire unboosted tier after a paralysis, while the rest augment its mildly lacking special bulk. Miltank should be paired with Pokemon that can account for its debilitating Fighting weakness. This includes Pokemon such as Weezing and Palossand, which, in return, appreciate Miltank checking special attackers such as Charizard. Stealth Rock setters such as Gigalith and Sandaconda can allow Miltank to run Heal Bell. These Pokemon heavily appreciate the cleric support Miltank then provides, as they are easily susceptible to status. Defensive Pokemon that are weak to Fire or Ice such as Ferroseed and Golbat appreciate the resistance Thick Fat Miltank provides. In return, Ferroseed can remove items from shared checks while Golbat can nullify Fighting-type attacks for Miltank.

sets.name: Toxic Orb Attacker
sets.description:
Galarian Linoone is a reliable revenge killer thanks to its Quick Feet ability and can hit decently hard with its status-boosted Facade. However, it can be worn down quickly between Toxic and entry hazards. Galarian Linoone is able to support teammates with its pivoting capability through Parting Shot. Knock Off lets it cripple Pokemon such as Type: Null and Tangela that rely on their items. Protect allows Galarian Linoone to safely activate its Toxic Orb and Quick Feet, block First Impression from Falinks and Fraxure, and scout against Choice item users such as Choice Scarf Golduck and Manectric. Galarian Linoone's Speed tier and ability to switch moves set it apart from other fast revenge killers like Choice Scarf Unfezant and Lycanroc-N. A set using Double-Edge over Facade with Eviolite gives it more bulk in exchange for the ability to immediately take advantage of Quick Feet and becomes more of a fast pivot than a revenge killer.

Wallbreakers such as Appletun and Marowak appreciate the ability to come in safely and pressure Pokemon that Galarian Linoone can pivot on such as Mawile and Stunfisk. In return, Galarian Linoone is able to pick off Pokemon weakened by them. Since Galarian Linoone is prone to being taken advantage of by Competitive and Defiant users such as Wigglytuff, Pawniard, and Falinks, checks to these Pokemon like Gourgeist for Wigglytuff and Galarian Rapidash for Pawniard and Falinks are needed. Galarian Linoone can also form a pivoting core with Manectric, Golduck, Morpeko, Raboot, or Boltund to wear down the opposing team. Parting Shot's Attack and Special Attack drops can also help setup sweepers like Galarian Rapidash and Drifblim have an easier time setting up. As Galarian Linoone will be frequently entering the field, entry hazard removal from Mr. Rime or Morpeko is appreciated too. Mareanie and Stunfisk can also pivot into Fighting-type moves such as Hitmonchan's Mach Punch for Galarian Linoone.

Aggron.overview: Aggron fits as both a strong wallbreaker and defensive wall in SS PU. Its STAB moves are naturally strong, and it has a fair amount of coverage and utility moves as well. Aggron's raw strength makes Choice Band sets extremely difficult to switch into and allows even uninvested variants to do a fair amount of damage. Aggron's typing makes it a great stop to common Pokemon like Ribombee and Galarian Articuno and grants a Toxic immunity, setting itself apart from other defensive Pokemon with Stealth Rock such as Regirock and Gigalith. However, its typing can hinder it against common Pokemon such as Scrafty and Sandaconda. No reliable recovery makes defensive sets vulnerable to being worn down as well.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Aggron is able to threaten most of the tier with its high base power STAB moves. Aqua Tail provides coverage for bulky Ground-types like Palossand and Sandaconda. Earthquake allows Aggron to OHKO opposing Aggron, in addition to evading chip from Rocky Helmet users such as Sandaconda. Superpower is an option to hit Ferroseed super effectively and deal more damage to Regirock, but it usually isn't worth it. Choice Band Aggron appreciates pivots such as Whimsicott and Uxie that lure passive Pokemon such as Aromatisse and Audino for it to take advantage of. Pokemon like Basculin and Archeops can exploit Aggron's typing to gain momentum, so it appreciates support from bulky Pokemon such as Jellicent and Sandaconda. Sandaconda and Uxie also spread paralysis for Aggron.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Aggron is great at sponging attacks from Ribombee, Mesprit, and other special attackers with limited coverage. Even without investment, its STAB moves hit hard and keep it from being passive. Protect makes playing around Choice-locked Pokemon like Gallade and Mesprit, as well as Future Sight users such as Galarian Articuno when they are paired with Pokemon that can threaten Aggron directly, much easier. Toxic is useful to wear down bulky Pokemon like Palossand and Tangela. Roar can rack up chip damage, especially when paired with Spikes from Froslass or Qwilfish. Roar also pairs amazingly with Future Sight users like Galarian Articuno to wallbreak. Wish Aromatisse and Healing Wish Mesprit are great tools to keep Aggron healthy. Fairy-types like Aromatisse and Whimsicott deal with Bulk Up Scrafty, which would otherwise comfortably set up on Aggron, and absorb Knock Off. Other Knock Off absorbers like Weezing and Qwilfish are also useful against Pokemon such as Sawk and Ferroseed. Pokemon like Charizard and Claydol, which can remove Spikes, assist Aggron in not getting worn down too quickly.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Solrock is a Stealth Rock setter that acts as a physical wall thanks to its decent Defense and access to Will-O-Wisp and a reliable recovery move, making it a good check to some physical attackers such as Persian and Stonjourner. It is also notable for having a decent matchup against spinners such as Hitmontop and Galarian Mr. Mime depending on its coverage. However, Solrock suffers from competition with other Stealth Rock setters such as Mawile and Palpitoad, both of which have a better typing and are easier to fit on teams. Mawile has access to Intimidate and plenty of really good resistances such as Ice, Grass, and Flying while Palpitoad has two great immunities in Electric and Water. Rock Slide gives Solrock a better matchup against common entry hazard removers like Mr. Rime, whereas Zen Headbutt is another option that helps against Fighting-types such as Throh and Falinks. Toxic can be an option over Will-O-Wisp to wear down bulkier Pokemon like Gourgeist-XL and Beheeyem, but in a lot of cases, Solrock needs the opposing Pokemon burned to check it easily. Colbur Berry can be used to check Throh, which it can't cripple with Will-O-Wisp, more easily. However, Solrock otherwise prefers the passive recovery from Leftovers.

Solrock struggles a lot against Dark-types such as Pawniard and Thievul, so Fighting-types like Throh, Falinks, and Hitmontop make really good teammates for it. They also benefit from Solrock's unique typing, since they tend to struggle against Psychic- and Flying-types such as Defog Silvally-Psychic and Vespiquen that Solrock has no trouble checking. Falinks can offensively check Swords Dance Silvally-Psychic and Ludicolo variants thanks to First Impression. Offensive Grass- and Water-types such as Silvally-Grass and Basculin can easily pressure Solrock, so bulky Grass-types such as Gourgeist and Roselia are recommended teammates for it. Solrock can also switch into Fire- and Flying-types such as Raboot and Vespiquen for Roselia and Gourgeist. Although Solrock has good Defense, its Special Defense is bad, so special walls such as Dusclops and Type: Null work well as teammates, since both of them can switch fairly well into wallbreakers that pressure Solrock like Ludicolo and Glaceon.

Claydol.overview: Claydol's unique qualities, movepool, and typing allow it to function as an interesting form of role compression on teams. It has access to Stealth Rock and Rapid Spin, making it a solid choice for either a Stealth Rock setter or a defensive spinner, although it cannot threaten most Ghost-types. Its typing and Levitate give it important resistances to Poison-, Psychic-, and Rock-type moves, letting it pivot into these moves from Pokemon such as Weezing, Mesprit, and Aggron, as well as two important immunities to Electric and Ground; these make it a stop to Volt Switch pivots and Pokemon locked into Earthquake in a pinch, as it fares badly against most of them otherwise. However, Claydol is very passive, heavily relying on Toxic to maintain a presence. It is forced to choose between two STAB moves that are exploitable, meaning it can struggle against foes such as Golbat and Togedemaru depending on the move it chooses. Its typing is also a double-edged sword, with weaknesses to Grass, Dark, Water, and Bug, making it easy to exploit by Pokemon such as Tsareena and Absol, and many of the Pokemon it would like to check can run these moves. Claydol also lacks recovery if it forgoes Leftovers, meaning it can be hard to check what it wants to over a long match.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Psychic has solid neutral coverage as Claydol's STAB move, letting it chip Flying-types such as Archeops and Charizard, but makes it harder to threaten Dark-types. Scorching Sands can be chosen as its STAB move due to its ability to spread burns and hit Dark-types, but it loses to Pokemon such as Golbat and Weezing. Teleport allows Claydol to gain momentum against Pokemon it forces out such as Choice-locked Togedemaru. Alternatively, Protect and Leftovers give Claydol more recovery, increase Toxic damage, and scout opposing Choice-locked Pokemon. However, this gives it a worse matchup against Knock Off users such as Absol and Gallade due to the lack of Colbur Berry. The Speed investment is to guarantee outspeeding fully invested base 80s after a Rapid Spin, such as Gallade and Mesprit, crippling them with a Toxic before they can respond. Claydol likes to have defensive support from Pokemon that can handle special attackers like Rotom, Charizard, and Basculin. Lanturn can take hits from all of them and cripple them with Toxic, and Assault Vest Lanturn specifically can soak up general special hits for Claydol. Ferroseed is another option, functioning as a Toxic sponge that can also check Grass- and Water-types. In return, Claydol can reduce the chip damage Lanturn takes with Rapid Spin and deal with Ground-types such as Sandaconda for both of them. Claydol often best fits on more defensive teams due to its lack of recovery, supportive capabilities, and lacking offensive presence; as such, it appreciates the cleric and Wish support Pokemon such as Aromatisse and Audino can give it.

Absol.overview: Absol is a good wallbreaker in the PU metagame thanks to a sky-high Attack stat, a spammable STAB option in Knock Off, and options to boost its Attack in Choice Band and Swords Dance. Access to priority in Sucker Punch, which is especially potent with Swords Dance, makes it harder to revenge kill. Its wide coverage options to hit standard Dark-type checks, like Iron Tail and Close Combat for Aromatisse and Regirock, and an extremely strong STAB Knock Off are its main draws over Sneasel. Unfortunately, Absol's poor bulk, few resistances, and weaknesses to common Fighting- and Bug-type moves in the tier leave it with little defensive utility. This means Absol struggles to get in, and due to its middling Speed tier as well as Sucker Punch potentially being worked around, it often gets forced out.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: The fourth move of choice depends on what Absol wants to deal with. Iron Tail takes care of bulky Fairy-types such as Aromatisse and Silvally-Fairy; however, Psycho Cut lets it 2HKO Weezing after Stealth Rock and does significant damage to Fighting-types like Hitmontop. Justified is run in order to punish Knock Offs from Pokemon such as Audino and Scrafty; however, Super Luck means Psycho Cut will critically hit half of the time. A Jolly nature is chosen to ensure Absol can outspeed Jolly Hitmontop, but an Adamant nature hits harder. Absol has trouble getting onto the field, so slow pivots such as Uxie can remedy this issue. They also help by baiting in Absol's prey, foes such as Rotom and Palossand, making it even easier for Absol to take something down. Fighting-types such as Hitmontop and Scrafty appreciate Absol's ability to weaken Poison- and Fairy-types with its coverage, making it easier for them to sweep. Absol appreciates Fighting-type checks and Pokemon that can pivot into U-turn, such as Aromatisse and Weezing, as they can punish these Pokemon that Absol dislikes.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Iron Tail takes out Fairy-types such as Aromatisse, while Close Combat takes care of Rock-types such as Regirock and Dark-types such as Scrafty. Play Rough can be used as a middle ground to hit Fighting-types such as Gurdurr and Hitmontop on a switch-in while hitting Fairy-types harder than Close Combat, but lacks the higher power of Iron Tail or Close Combat. Life Orb is preferred, but Black Glasses gives better longevity and the ability to bluff a Choice Band set. Justified is run to punish Knock Offs from Pokemon like Uxie. However, Super Luck, when used with Psycho Cut, results in a critical hit half of the time. Sticky Webs support is heavily appreciated due to Absol's middling Speed tier, so setters like Ribombee and Vikavolt are great partners for it. Vikavolt also breaks through physical walls such as Regirock. On bulkier teams, slow pivots such as Lanturn can help Swords Dance Absol wallbreak or sweep a team by slowly wearing down its checks whilst providing setup opportunities. Hazard setters such as Palossand also help Swords Dance Absol by moving many faster threats into the range of a boosted Sucker Punch, like Silvally-Fairy. Offensive sweepers such as Quiver Dance Ribombee appreciate Absol's wallbreaking, as it makes it easier for them to clean late-game.

Regirock.overview: Regirock's incredible physical bulk, typing, and access to Stealth Rock make it a premier physical wall in the tier. It can check a multitude of threats, like Archeops, Sneasel, Togedemaru, and Scyther, giving it multiple opportunities to set Stealth Rock reliably. However, it struggles against common wallbreakers like Gallade and can get overwhelmed rather quickly due to its lack of reliable recovery. Lastly, it suffers from competition from Gigalith, which can switch into threats like Charizard more reliably thanks to Sand Stream giving it better special bulk.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description: Thanks to its typing and splendid physical bulk, Regirock makes for a sturdy Stealth Rock setter capable of dishing out solid damage thanks to Body Press. The given EV spread allows Regirock to always avoid the 2HKO from Tsareena and Choice Band Aggron, while Clear Body lets it block Parting Shot. Rock Blast allows Regirock to break Substitute and Focus Sash from Pokemon like Rotom-F and lead Archeops, while Stone Edge hits consistently harder. Toxic gives Regirock a way to cripple walls like Palossand and Jellicent, whereas Thunder Wave can be used to cripple more offensive threats such as Whimsicott. Partners that can take on special attackers like Magneton and Magmortar that Regirock struggles against are appreciated. Lanturn stands out as a solid option, being able to further support Regirock with Heal Bell. Answers to Fighting- and Grass-types like Gurdurr and Tsareena are also appreciated; this makes Weezing a stellar partner. Charizard is another great teammate, and it appreciates Regirock checking threats like Archeops.

Vespiquen.overview: The following analysis was written in a prior iteration of the PU metagame and as a result does not accurately reflect the current state of the tier, where Vespiquen is considered outclassed and not worth using. This page will be updated later to reflect this.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
Heavy-Duty Boots lets Vespiquen circumvent its 4x Stealth Rock weakness, making it a viable option for checking Grass- and Fighting-types like Silvally-Grass, Leafeon, Throh, Falinks, and Hitmontop and as a slow pivot with U-turn. Roost gives Vespiquen a reliable recovery option, and allows for more chances to stall moves like Silvally-Psychic's Multi-Attack with Pressure. Defog and Pressure pair nicely together, as this means you can PP stall Toxic Spikes and Spikes from Mareanie and Roselia for the entirety of the game. Alternatively, Toxic Spikes cripples foes, while Aromatherapy lets Vespiquen function as a cleric. Vespiquen’s Speed alongside U-turn is excellent for slow pivoting, giving you ample opportunities to bring in wallbreakers. Air Slash makes it easier to defeat Gourgeist-XL that have burned Vespiquen, but Acrobatics is an option to have a strong STAB move if Throh or Leafeon choose to remove Vespiquen's item with Knock Off.

Vespiquen fits best on bulky offense and balance teams that can deal with Defog deterrents like Falinks and Pawniard, so Silvally-Electric, Dubwool, Hitmontop, and Throh are excellent teammates, as they not only check Pawniard and act as Knock Off absorbers, the latter two are also Rock-type checks. Palpitoad is very notable as a partner; it resists Rock, checks Pawniard, and handles Fire- and Electric-types like Raboot and Manectric, while Vespiquen checks Grass-types in return. Vespiquen's reliance on Heavy-Duty Boots means it is not optimal to have its item removed by Knock Off unless you are using Acrobatics, so Knock Off absorbers like Rocky Helmet Mawile, Silvally formes, Colbur Berry Musharna, and Throh make it easier for Vespiquen to not be affected by Stealth Rock damage. Strong wallbreakers that can break Rock- and Ice-types, like Falinks, Silvally formes, and Stonjourner, appreciate the safety from slow U-turn pivoting; Vespiquen benefits from the removal of such Pokemon, since it makes it much easier for it to use Defog. Vespiquen does not appreciate Ice-type Pokemon like Mr. Rime, Glaceon, and Lapras; Type: Null, Mr. Rime, Klang, Throh, and Lapras are fine options for mitigating this weakness, using Toxic, pivoting, or phasing them out to deal with them.

Magmortar.overview: Magmortar is an extremely threatening wallbreaker in PU thanks to its incredible coverage and very high Special Attack. These allow it to break through many special walls that aim to check Fire-types such as Regirock and Jellicent. Magmortar also has a decent Speed stat, with a Timid nature allowing it to outspeed base 80 Speed Pokemon such as non-Choice Scarf Mesprit. However, Magmortar is still outrun by many common threats such as Basculin and Silvally. Its merely fine Speed combined with its lacking physical bulk make Magmortar relatively simple to revenge kill compared to Charizard, which has much more long-term potential. Finally, Magmortar is forced to choose between being extremely vulnerable to all entry hazards and giving up a boosting item.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Thunderbolt hits Water- and Flying-types such as Jellicent and Charizard. Focus Blast hits Rock-types such as Gigalith and Regirock as well as Scrafty. The last slot is very customizable depending on your team's needs: Scorching Sands gives Magmortar a better matchup against Lanturn and opposing Magmortar while also being a safer way to hit Rock-types. Taunt prevents recovery from the likes of Jellicent and Scrafty as well as Stealth Rock from setters like Druddigon in a pinch. Toxic is a good source of chip damage versus walls such as Jellicent and Gigalith. Overheat is a powerful nuke for Choice Specs Magmortar. Flame Charge is another option to turn Magmortar into a late-game cleaner, although it should only be run with Heavy-Duty Boots and a Timid nature. Magmortar can switch into a few resisted hits from Pokemon such as Whimsicott and Ribombee, but it is easily worn down and better brought in by pivots such as Lanturn and Rotom. It can also switch into predicted U-turns from Pokemon like Togedemaru and Archeops to fish for burn with Flame Body, although this can be risky. Setup sweepers such as Scrafty and Quiver Dance Ribombee make for great teammates that can effectively exploit Magmortar's breaking power. Magmortar greatly appreciates entry hazard removers if it opts to not run Heavy-Duty Boots: Silvally-Fairy and Rotom are good Defoggers that can also bring Magmortar in via pivoting.

Glaceon.overview: The following analysis was written in a prior iteration of the PU metagame and as a result does not accurately reflect the current state of the tier, where Glaceon is considered outclassed and not worth using. This page will be updated later to reflect this.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Glaceon is one of PU's scariest wallbreakers, capable of putting immense pressure on even some of the tier's best special walls in Throh and Type: Null as a result of its sheer power. Freeze-Dry allows Glaceon to threaten Ice-resistant Water-types like Pyukumuku and Corsola, and it's also Glaceon's best option against Lapras. Shadow Ball allows Glaceon to OHKO Galarian Mr. Mime and threaten specially defensive Mr. Rime. It also hits Klang and opposing Glaceon harder than any other move Glaceon can viably run. Water Pulse targets Carkol, though it doesn't have much use outside of that. Frost Breath can allow Glaceon to get past bulky Calm Mind and Cosmic Power users like Musharna and Gothitelle in a pinch, but the move is virtually useless outside of this one purpose and cuts into Glaceon's already limited coverage. A Timid nature can be used to outspeed Adamant Falinks and Choice Band Fraxure as well as Speed tie with offensive Roselia.
