Glaceon could opt to use Choice Scarf to act as a revenge killer rather than a wallbreaker. Although this allows Glaceon to take care of +1 Adamant Fraxure and circumvent typical offensive checks like Silvally-Grass and Raichu, such a set severely reduces Glaceon's power and faces serious competition from Mr. Rime and Galarian Mr. Mime due to their higher Speed tiers, better coverage, and access to Healing Wish. Glaceon's low Speed and poor defensive typing make it very easy to offensively pressure, so it appreciates having bulky teammates to fall back on in the face of faster Fire-, Fighting-, and Rock-types. Vibrava gives Glaceon an easier time switching in by removing entry hazards with Defog and generating momentum with U-turn. It's worth noting that a lot of Pokemon that Vibrava baits in and pivots out against, like Gloom and Togetic, find themselves easily exploited by Glaceon. Mareanie absorbs Toxic Spikes upon switching in, can wear teams down with its own Toxic Spikes, and also softens up bulky foes that depend on their item, like Type: Null and Lapras, with Knock Off. Although Glaceon is strong, it lacks the coverage to bypass dedicated Ice-type answers such as Munchlax and Klang. Wallbreakers like Mawile, Hitmontop, and Flame Orb Throh help to remedy this issue, and they appreciate Glaceon taking on physical walls like Mareanie, Shiinotic, and Gourgeist-XL. Mawile also provides Stealth Rock support to put further pressure on teams, while Hitmontop removes entry hazards with Rapid Spin. Glaceon has an easier time breaking through teams with Spikes support, essentially 2HKOing Type: Null after Stealth Rock and three layers of Spikes. Roselia is a great Spikes setter, capable of incapacitating foes like Klang with Sleep Powder and making them easier for Glaceon to overwhelm. Pivots like Manectric and Silvally-Bug can give Glaceon more opportunities to switch in, with both examples doubling as late-game sweepers that can exploit the holes that Glaceon leaves in teams earlier on. These pivots can annoy Pokemon like Lapras and Pawniard, while Glaceon can threaten Palpitoad and Carkol.

sets.name: Cleric
sets.description: Because of its decent bulk and near-unique access to both Wish and Heal Bell, Glaceon can serve as a cleric for balance teams. Freeze-Dry is used instead of Ice Beam to hit foes like Lapras and Seaking harder. Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Glaceon from being worn down by entry hazards, which allows it to more easily switch around and better preserve the health of it and its teammates. This immunity to entry hazards, alongside Glaceon's higher Special Attack and natural defenses, helps to separate it from Togetic, another cleric that similarly has access to Wish and Heal Bell. Although Glaceon has higher Defense than Special Defense, its poor defensive typing is easily exploited by many of the tier's physical attackers, including Mawile, Falinks, and Silvally-Rock. There are fewer specially offensive Pokemon that can do the same, and opting for a specially defensive set provides defensive teams with a secondary check to threats like Ludicolo and opposing Glaceon. Stunfisk and physically defensive Mawile appreciate having their lack of reliable recovery mitigated by Wish support, and in return, they can absorb Knock Off and check threats that Glaceon is vulnerable to, such as Pawniard and Stonjourner. Pyukumuku can also absorb Knock Off as well as wall setup sweepers like Falinks and Crustle that threaten Glaceon thanks to Unaware. In return, Glaceon can relieve Pyukumuku of any potential status conditions, which is especially useful for Rest variants. Stronger special attackers like Beheeyem and Raichu are capable of overwhelming Glaceon, meaning that it should never be the only special wall on balance teams. Other specially bulky Pokemon such as Type: Null, Dusclops, Vibrava, and Munchlax make for great partners because of this, with Rest allowing all three examples to soak up status conditions for Glaceon as well. Glaceon allows these examples to rely less on Rest by providing them with Wish support. Checks to Fighting-types are useful partners, since they can often switch into Glaceon with ease. Mareanie is a notable example, since it can consistently check Fighting-types thanks to both Recover and Regenerator, further wears teams down through Scald and either Toxic or Toxic Spikes, takes pressure off of Glaceon's team by absorbing Toxic Spikes, and stops setup sweepers like Falinks in their tracks with Haze.

Gallade.overview: Gallade makes for a potent wallbreaker with its raw strength, coverage, and decent Speed tier. It does a great job at dismantling slower teams, as it can threaten balance staples with its STAB moves, such as Regirock and Weezing. Gallade is able to distinguish itself from other Fighting-types like Scrafty and Sawk with its immediate power, secondary STAB, and ability to boost with Swords Dance. However, its Speed tier still leaves much to be desired, as it can easily be pressured by offensive Pokemon like Archeops and Charizard. Gallade finds itself competing with other Fighting-type wallbreakers like Scrafty that are weaker initially but have more defensive utility.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Gallade is able to bolster its naturally high Attack with Life Orb to easily muscle past Pokemon like Gigalith without the need for hazards. Swords Dance elevates its power even further, helping net OHKOs on bulky Pokemon like Weezing once boosted, while generally being harder to switch into. It also provides the necessary strength to get past Palossand and Aromatisse. Lum Berry provides more setup opportunities against status users, such as Gigalith and Regirock. Sticky Web support from Pokemon like Ribombee, Galvantula, and Vikavolt allows Gallade to outspeed Pokemon like Silvally-Ghost and Lycanroc. These Sticky Web setters are also able to pivot Gallade into Pokemon such as Gigalith and Togedemaru. Gallade's middling Speed tier makes it rather easy for it to be checked by common Pokemon like Charizard and Silvally-Fairy, so Gallade appreciates having a defensive backbone with Pokemon like Druddigon and Sandaconda to fall back on. Gallade's average bulk can be mitigated with pivots like Togedemaru and Whimsicott to get it in safely on Pokemon like Weezing.

Froslass.overview: Froslass makes for a capable wallbreaker thanks to its usable Attack and great Speed tier combined with its unique typing. It also has access to utility moves such as Trick and Spikes, allowing it to cripple and overwhelm its answers; it can even run a dedicated Spikes set, although it becomes much weaker without a boosting item. However, its below average Attack often leaves it over-reliant on its own Spikes to get past defensive behemoths like Regirock, while its typing and bulk leave it easily revenge killed by faster threats such as Lycanroc, Choice Scarf Togedemaru, and Sneasel as well as priority moves like Sucker Punch and Accelrock.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Triple Axel is a strong, albeit unreliable, STAB move. Icicle Crash is an option, as it's more reliable despite being weaker; it also avoids Rough Skin and Flame Body from the likes of Druddigon and Coalossal. Trick allows Froslass to cripple its answers such as Scrafty and Aromatisse, while Ice Shard allows it to revenge kill foes like Ribombee. Despite seeming odd on a set using a Choice item, Spikes lets Froslass take advantage of the many Pokemon it forces out. Froslass's subpar bulk means it appreciates being brought in via partners like Galarian Articuno and Scyther; The former can also act as a Defog deterrent, and they both appreciate the Spikes Froslass sets. Pokemon like Quiver Dance Ribombee and Dragon Dance Charizard have an easier time cleaning late-game after Froslass has weakened down walls such as Regirock, Aromatisse, and Wishiwashi.

sets.name: Spikes
sets.description: Froslass's great Speed and typing make it a potent Spikes setter, as it's capable of pressuring common spinners such as Tsareena. Taunt prevents Pokemon like Miltank from recovering and also allows Froslass to keep its Spikes on the field against Defog users like Silvally-Fairy. Wallbreakers like Magmortar and Archeops greatly appreciate the Spikes Froslass sets, as it gives them an easier time breaking through Gigalith and Regirock, respectively. Pokemon like Regirock, Weezing, and Lanturn can switch into threats such as Lycanroc, Aggron, and Togedemaru that force out Froslass, respectively.

Rotom.overview: Rotom is a quite versatile Pokemon thanks to its solid typing both offensively and defensively, great Speed, and decent movepool. These traits allow it to perform well as either a Choice Scarf user or a Defogger. Electric / Ghost is a near unresisted typing, barring Shiftry, all of which can be pivoted out against with Volt Switch. Defensively, Rotom resists or is immune to various common attacks from Pokemon such as Scyther and Passimian, although has to watch out for common coverage moves such as Knock Off. Rotom's Speed allows it to outspeed threatening breakers such as Nasty Plot Mesprit and Magmortar and for its Choice Scarf set to outspeed other common Choice Scarf users like Passimian and Mesprit. There are other Electric- and Ghost-types that give it competition as a Choice Scarf user, such as Togedemaru with its higher Speed and valuable Steel typing, and Haunter with its higher Speed and Special Attack alongside support moves such as Destiny Bond. However, Rotom's unique type combination and access to both Trick and Volt Switch make it a great option over the other two.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf allows Rotom to utilize its solid Speed to outspeed various other Choice Scarf users, such as Kabutops and Mesprit, as well as gain momentum with Volt Switch. While Trick is run to cripple specially defensive Pokemon that may try to switch in on Rotom, such as Lanturn and Gigalith, it can also be used to potentially put a stop to bulky setup Pokemon such as Scrafty and Aromatisse. Rotom is best used as a revenge killer or brought in by slow pivots such as defensive Mesprit and defensive Silvally-Fairy, which furthermore form a solid VoltTurn core with it. Wallbreakers such as Aggron and Magmortar benefit from being brought in through Rotom's Volt Switch.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description: Rotom can serve as a solid Defog user with its good matchup against various entry hazard setters such as Mesprit and Palossand. Furthermore, it is able to cripple various other hazard setters such as Gigalith and Druddigon with Will-O-Wisp. Will-O-Wisp also powers up Hex, which should only be run alongside it. Thunderbolt is an option for the last slot if you want to give Rotom more of an offensive presence, although Pain Split is an option to increase Rotom's longevity that pairs well with its low HP stat. Colbur Berry allows for Rotom to better check Fighting-types and other Knock Off users, such as Passimian and Scyther, but Heavy-Duty Boots is a secondary option so it can take no damage from Stealth Rock. While Rotom does have a nice defensive typing, it is recommended to not switch it into attacks too many times, as it is easily worn down with its only okay bulk, especially without Pain Split. Pokemon that are easily worn down by entry hazards, such as Silvally-Steel and Uxie, appreciate Rotom's hazard removal.

Rotom-Frost.overview: Rotom-F is a moderately fast wallbreaker capable of dishing out major damage thanks to its STAB BoltBeam coverage, further supported by its access to Nasty Plot. Additionally, Rotom-Frost has an excellent support movepool, through featuring Will-O-Wisp, Defog, Pain Split, and Trick. Rotom-F is also able to make use of its wonderful offensive typing as a Defogger to threaten common entry hazard setters such as Druddigon and Sandaconda. However, Rotom-F has a limited offensive movepool outside of its STAB moves, which leaves it completely walled by several common Pokemon in the tier like Lanturn and Togedemaru. On top of this, its poor defensive typing, lack of reliable recovery, and susceptibility to Knock Off give Rotom-F severe longevity issues compared to other entry hazard removers such as Tsareena, Charizard, and Whimsicott. Additionally, Vikavolt is much more useful to many teams as an offensive Electric-type pivot thanks to its higher Special Attack, better coverage, and access to Roost.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: With Nasty Plot and Volt Switch, Rotom-F is capable of wearing down common specially defensive tanks such as Gigalith and Aromatisse. Pain Split is an option to replenish HP and punish switch-ins with high HP stats like Lanturn, which can easily switch into boosted Blizzard. Will-O-Wisp, on the other hand, allows Rotom-F to cripple Togedemaru and Gigalith. Offensive partners such as Archeops and Whimsicott make for fine pairings, as they can offensively check common Fighting-types like Scrafty and Gallade while also helping Rotom-F in wearing down Lanturn and Whimsicott, respectively. Archeops also completes a fantastic VoltTurn core thanks to its ability to pivot on bulky Ground- and Grass-types like Sandaconda, Palossand, and Tangela in order to bring in Rotom-F safely.

sets.name: Offensive Defog
sets.description: Pain Split provides Rotom-F with the ability to regain HP while chipping bulkier switch-ins like Lanturn, Gigalith, and Miltank. However, Will-O-Wisp is an option for crippling Steel-types like specially defensive Aggron and Togedemaru. Rotom-Frost partners excellently with Lanturn, as it creates a good VoltTurn core and provides a key Fire-type resistance for Pokemon that threaten Rotom-F like Charizard and Magmortar. Additionally, Lanturn enjoys Rotom-F's ability to offensively check Grass-types like Gourgeist and Trevenant. Other wallbreakers that can take advantage of Gigalith, such as Gourgeist-S and Poliwrath, make for good offensive partners.

Uxie.overview: Uxie stands out as a great pivot in PU thanks to its natural Speed, bulk, and support options. Uxie's Speed allows it to pivot out with U-turn before Pokemon like Aggron can otherwise muscle past it. Uxie is able to check weaker physical attackers such as Lycanroc and Archeops and potentially cripple them with Thunder Wave or Knock Off, but it can be worn down due to the lack of reliable recovery. Uxie also faces heavy competition from Mesprit, which offers more utility in Healing Wish and is less vulnerable to bulky setup sweepers like Scrafty and Sandaconda.

sets.name: Defensive Stealth Rock
sets.description: Uxie is able to consistently set Stealth Rock with its natural bulk and pivot against entry hazard removers that it cannot do much to like Claydol and Silvally-Steel. Knock Off is helpful for crippling other passive Pokemon like Gigalith and Aromatisse. Alternatively, Thunder Wave is a great tool for stopping setup sweepers that do not mind Psychic such as Mesprit and Silvally-Fairy, while also targeting Defoggers like Charizard that force Uxie out. Memento is also an option to support frailer setup sweepers such as Ribombee and Absol. Colbur Berry allows Uxie to stay in against opposing Knock Off users like Absol and hinder it with Thunder Wave or pivot out and get some chip damage. Leftovers is another option to let Uxie stay healthy, as it has no consistent recovery of its own. While Uxie's bulk is well-rounded, it can struggle with stronger special attackers like Ribombee and Charizard due to the lack of Special Defense investment. Specially defensive Pokemon such as Silvally-Steel and Lanturn can help cover for Uxie so it will not be overwhelmed by these special attackers. Uxie is able to take advantage of U-turn to get wallbreakers like Absol and Aggron in safely or form pivot cores with Pokemon such as Passimian and Rotom. Aromatisse helps Uxie against Dark-types like Absol and Scrafty and can provide Wish support and Uxie can pressure Weezing in return.

Mesprit.overview: Mesprit stands out as by far the most versatile Pokemon in PU thanks to its solid stat distribution, excellent ability in Levitate, and wide support movepool with moves such as U-turn, Healing Wish, Trick, Nasty Plot, and Stealth Rock. Mesprit is extremely good at role compression and can fulfill a variety of different needs for your team, although its counters rarely differ too much based on the set. While Mesprit is a solid wallbreaker and has the speed to beat out slower offensive and defensive staples like Tsareena and Weezing, it's still outpaced by a large portion of the metagame. Combined with a lack of any reliable recovery, this gives Mesprit extreme longevity issues, particularly Choice Scarf sets, which will rarely outspeed any other boosted Pokemon. Furthermore, Mesprit's special coverage can be lacking at times, as Mesprit can struggle against Steel-types such as Aggron and Togedemaru. Ultimately Mesprit's role compression can be very useful for covering weaknesses, but Mesprit will never be the best at any one role it attempts to cover.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf lets Mesprit revenge kill Pokemon such as Sneasel and +1 Dragon Dance Scrafty. Many different teammates appreciate Healing Wish support from Mesprit, from recovery-lacking wallbreakers like Magmortar to sweepers looking to set up twice such as Dragon Dance Scrafty. However, Trick can be run in this slot instead to cripple bulky Pokemon that otherwise wall Mesprit such as Jellicent and check bulky setup sweepers such as Cosmic Power Claydol. Mesprit rarely has opportunities to guarantee a safe switch in and needs to be brought in when a teammate has been KOed, via good predictions, or using pivoting. Slow pivots such as Silvally-Fairy and Lanturn are great options to safely bring Mesprit in and form a VoltTurn core. This will ideally be supplemented with a strong wallbreaker such as Sneasel or Trevenant ready to be brought in on a convenient pivot to do some damage.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: Nasty Plot turns Mesprit into a fairly powerful wallbreaker, being able to 2HKO most of the tier after a single boost. The last moveslot is fairly customizable; Shadow Ball is Mesprit's best move for Steel-types like Togedemaru and Galarian Stunfisk, but Thunderbolt is an effective way to threaten Flying- and Water-types like Charizard and Jellicent before Mesprit sets up. Colbur Berry is the preferred item, as it makes Mesprit harder to revenge kill with Dark-types like Sneasel and Absol and fare better against Fighting-types like Gallade and Gurdurr. Life Orb is a more powerful item that might even remove the need for Mesprit to set up, but the lack of longevity is such that Mesprit is unlikely to have many chances to wallbreak. A Timid nature allows Mesprit to outspeed Modest Magmortar and Jolly Tsareena among other threats, but Modest can be run for more damage output. Tsareena is a good partner because it can use U-turn to bring Mesprit in for easy setup opportunities on Pokemon such as Weezing. Due to Mesprit's lack of longevity, it often pairs well with a secondary wallbreaker like Magmortar or Archeops to keep up offensive pressure after Mesprit has been KOed. Sweepers and cleaners such as Ribombee and Lycanroc can make good use of Mesprit's wallbreaking to clean up the opposing team.

sets.name: Offensive Stealth Rock
sets.description: Mesprit's final moveslot is largely dependent on how badly you want Healing Wish on your team. U-turn is far more useful for keeping up momentum and preventing Mesprit from becoming too predictable, but Healing Wish can be an effective way to supplement setup sweepers such as Dragon Dance Charizard. Mesprit's best qualities are its good speed for a Stealth Rock setter and favorable matchup against several entry hazard removers such as Golbat and Hitmontop. Despite this set's lack of defensive investment, having few weaknesses means it often has the time to set up Stealth Rock and fire off multiple attacks. Few weaknesses and access to U-turn allow Mesprit to keep up momentum in a way few Stealth Rock users can, making it an ideal pick for more offensive teams. Its inability to deal much damage to special walls or Steel-types means that wallbreakers such as Trevenant and Charizard make for good partners. Mesprit appreciates Pokemon that can punish U-turn, such as Rocky Helmet Druddigon and Coalossal, which can discourage Pokemon like Togedemaru from freely pivoting versus Mesprit. Mesprit can also opt for a more defensively oriented spread that runs both U-turn and Healing Wish while foregoing Dazzling Gleam. However, this set runs into competition from Uxie, which is both faster and bulkier than Mesprit at the cost of being mildly less threatening due to its lower offenses and inability to bluff more threatening sets.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Shadow Ball is Mesprit's best way to hit Steel- and Psychic-types, U-turn eases Mesprit's reliance on predictions while gaining momentum in the process, and Trick can cripple switch-ins such as Articuno and Galarian Stunfisk. Choice Specs Mesprit is extremely prediction reliant, so having at least one of U-turn and Trick can be vital for a safer option that does not leave Mesprit Choice locked into an exploitable attack. Even with Dazzling Gleam, Dark-types greatly hinder Mesprit's ability to freely spam Psychic, so a solid Dark-type answer such as Silvally-Fairy or Aromatisse is important. Mesprit is not the strongest wallbreaker around, so entry hazard setters such as Froslass and Regirock are advised to supplement its damage output. Weaker or non-boosting cleaners such as Dragon Dance Charizard and Tsareena are ideal Pokemon to make use of Mesprit's wallbreaking. Mesprit will also require a solid defensive core with blanket checks such as Palossand, Jellicent, and Weezing ready to cover the wide variety of threats capable of revenge killing Mesprit after minimal chip damage.

Gigalith.overview: Gigalith’s excellent natural bulk in tandem with Sand Stream allows it to act as one of PU’s most wisely useful Pokemon. Its typing allows it to resist common threats such as Galarian Articuno, Scyther, and Charizard, and, with base 135 attack it is by no means passive. However, Gigalith has no means of recovery outside of Leftovers and is prone to being worn down. Its pure Rock typing can be a detriment at times, as Pokemon such as Hitmontop and Tsareena can come in on it for free and proceed to remove Gigalith’s hazards while threatening it out with their STAB moves.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Stone Edge can be run over Rock Blast for more immediate damage, but its low PP and accuracy make it unreliable at times. Earthquake prevents Pokemon like Togedemaru and Aggron from taking advantage of Gigalith. Protect is used to scout for Choice-locked Pokemon such as Trevenant and Togedemaru, as well as to gain additional Leftovers recovery and rack up residual Sandstorm damage. Toxic can be run to cripple Pokemon such as Whimsicott and punish safe switch-ins such as Regirock and Palossand, which would otherwise come in on it for free. Gigalith should be paired with team members that can deal with Water-, Grass-, or Fighting-types, such as Lanturn, Ferroseed, and Weezing. Lanturn is also able to support Gigalith with Heal Bell, allowing it to better check Pokemon like Charizard that commonly run Toxic, while Ferroseed can cripple switchins like Charizard with Knock Off while giving Gigalith switch-in opportunities. Other teammates such as Scyther and Whimsicott appreciate Gigalith’s ability to handle Fire- and Flying-types, and Whimsicott also deals with the Water- and Ground-types that give Gigalith trouble.

sets.name: SubSalac
sets.description:
Swoobat finds a niche in PU as a late-game sweeper, utilizing its ability in Simple and access to Substitute to acquire boosts from Calm Mind and Salac Berry to empower its Stored Power. Substitute provides Swoobat with an opportunity to set up multiple Calm Minds, letting it avoid status such as Toxic from Klinklang and helping it activate its Salac Berry. Stored Power utilizes the boosts from Calm Mind and Salac Berry and allows Swoobat to break through specially defensive walls such as Type: Null, Lickilicky, and Unaware Pyukumuku. Heat Wave serves as coverage for Steel- and Dark-types such as Klinklang, Mawile, and Pawniard. Alternatively, Roost provides Swoobat with recovery, letting it set up multiple Substitutes. Nasty Plot is a notable mention over Calm Mind, providing Swoobat with immediate wallbreaking power at the cost of not improving its special bulk, giving it worse matchups against threats like Shadow Ball Beheeyem and Calm Mind Drifblim. Thanks to Simple, Salac Berry provides Swoobat with a +2 boost to Speed, helping it outspeed offensive checks such as Choice Scarf Manectric and Golduck. As an alternative, Kee Berry boosts Swoobat's Defense, making it harder to revenge kill with priority moves like Pawniard's Sucker Punch and Falinks's First Impression.

Swoobat is mainly found on offensive teams that can weaken its checks and enable it to set up and sweep. Pairing Swoobat with Fighting-types such as Throh, Falinks, and Hitmonchan is ideal, since they provide a check to Steel- and Dark-types like Klinklang and Pawniard, especially if Swoobat is not running Heat Wave. Furthermore, they can threaten specially defensive walls like Type: Null and Lickilicky, two foes that can pressure Swoobat with Shadow Claw and Knock Off, respectively. Swoobat is susceptible to priority Shadow Sneak from Gourgeist and Dusknoir, so answers to them like Unfezant and Morpeko make for good partners. Pivots such as Boltund, Golduck, and the aforementioned Morpeko can bring Swoobat safely into battle and provide it with more setup opportunities, with Morpeko also providing Parting Shot support. Memento support from Alolan Dugtrio is valuable, weakening a foe and letting Swoobat set up safely. Fellow special attackers like Lilligant and Glaceon can cripple and weaken shared checks like Klinklang and Type: Null, helping Swoobat clean late-game. Physically defensive walls like Stunfisk and Sandslash complement Swoobat by serving as checks to revenge killers like Choice Scarf Unfezant and Boltund while setting up entry hazards to wear down opposing foes; in return, they appreciate Swoobat setting up and threatening their checks like Appletun, Lilligant, and Golduck. The aforementioned Sandslash as well as Defog users such as Drifblim and Silvally-Rock can help remove Stealth Rock, keeping Swoobat healthy to enable more setup opportunities.

Gurdurr.overview: Gurdurr is able to solidify itself in SS PU as a consistent Defogger with fair bulk. It is able to cripple all entry hazard setters with Knock Off or Drain Punch, which is particularly effective against Gigalith and Regirock. Gurdurr's reasonable bulk allows it to check a fair amount of Pokemon in the tier in a pinch too. However, Gurdurr still finds itself overwhelmed by common special attackers like Whimsicott and Charizard. It also competes with Hitmontop as an entry hazard remover; Gurdurr is more bulky, but Hitmontop is more offensive and has better coverage options.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description: Gurdurr is able to 2HKO Archeops with Drain Punch and avoid being 2HKOed by Magmortar due to the recovery. It can absorb Scalds from Pokemon like Lanturn without worry thanks to Guts. Knock Off hits Psychic-types like Mesprit and Galarian Articuno and wears down Weezing. Rock Slide allows Gurdurr to nail Flying-types such as Charizard, Vikavolt, and Scyther on the switch. Mach Punch picks off weakened Pokemon like Kabutops and Choice Scarf Togedemaru. This works especially well when running Bulk Up over Defog, but it is hard to justify over Scrafty. Toxic wears down Pokemon it cannot threaten, like Silvally-Fairy and Palossand. Defensively, Gurdurr has solid synergy with Regirock and Gigalith, as they can consistently switch into Flying-types like Charizard and appreciate Gurdurr removing Spikes and absorbing status. Charizard checks Ribombee and Whimsicott for Gurdurr. Silvally-Fairy and Aromatisse are able to absorb Knock Off so Gurdurr can keep its Eviolite, and they appreciate it wearing down bulky Poison-types in return. Aromatisse provides Wish support too. Bulky Ghost-types such as Cofagrigus and Palossand are not very bothered by Knock Off, making wallbreakers like Haunter useful. Haunter and other special wallbreakers appreciate Gurdurr checking Gigalith and keeping Stealth Rock off the field in return.

Sawk.overview: Among the myriad of Fighting-types in PU, Sawk tries to stand out thanks to its above average Speed tier that allows it to overcome certain threats of the tier such as Gallade, Mesprit, and Magmortar. Sawk also has very good coverage, its movepool including moves like Knock Off, Poison Jab, Stone Edge, and Earthquake which, coupled with its access to Mold Breaker allow it to defeat the most common switch-ins to other Fighting-types, such as Weezing, Charizard, and Whimsicott. Sawk is very frail though, but this problem can be handled thanks to its ability Sturdy, allowing it to survive a hit from full HP and retaliate, making it a dangerous threat to offensive archetypes. However, it has no real defensive utility, and nothing in its movepool pushes it over the edge, so Fighting-types such as Gallade and Hitmontop are often preferred over it.

sets.name: Choice Attacker
sets.description: This set makes switching into Sawk's Close Combat a really difficult task that only a few pokemon such as Aromatisse, Uxie, and Weezing can afford to accomplish. But Sawk's coverage makes up for that problem: Earthquake, paired with its ability Mold Breaker allows it to beat Weezing with Earthquake and eases prediction against Rotom, while Knock Off is good for getting rid of items, as well as hitting Psychic- and Ghost-types such as Mesprit, Uxie, and Gourgeist-S. Poison Jab rounds off the set, hitting Fairy-types such as Aromatisse and Ribombee super effectively. Sawk greatly appreciates teammates that are capable of bringing it in against Pokemon like Gigalith, Regirock, and Aggron with pivoting moves, such as Archeops, Togedemaru, and Scyther. Cleaners such as Ribombee really appreciate Sawk's ability to get rid of their counters such as Regirock, Gigalith, and Weezing, and Ribombee can also set up Sticky Web, making Sawk a lot harder to revenge kill. However, if Sticky Web is not set up, Sawk is super easy to revenge kill and needs a strong defensive core to back it up. Therefore, hazard setters like Weezing and Gigalith also make for good partners, improving Sawk’s wallbreaking potential.

sets.name: Sturdy Boots
sets.description: This set makes good use of Sawk's Sturdy ability and Heavy-Duty Boots keeping it intact. Knock Off is its main coverage option, allowing it to deal good damage to Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Jellicent, Mesprit, and Claydol. Knock Off can also make Sawk a lot harder to revenge kill by getting rid of Choice Scarf from Pokémon such as Mesprit. Poison Jab hits Fairy-types such as Silvally-Fairy and Ribombee super effectively, and Earthquake deals good damage to Neutralizing Gas Weezing and Lanturn. This Sawk set works particularly well on offensive teams thanks to its ability to stop sweeps, as it is able to revenge kill a lot of threats such as Scrafty, Lycanroc, and Silvally-Steel. Cleaners such as Ribombee and Silvally-Ghost really appreciate Sawk's ability to wear down their checks such as Golbat, Sandaconda, and Weezing.

Whimsicott.overview: Whimsicott is a very versatile Pokemon; its good offensive Fairy typing and immaculate Speed tier let it revenge kill Pokemon such as Scrafty and Swords Dance Gallade, and it has a defensive presence with its great typing, Prankster, and ability to annoy opposing Pokemon with status moves. It is difficult to play around due to the unpredictability that comes with the great variety of sets it can run and its Speed. However, Whimsicott lacks the Special Attack and coverage to deal much damage. This makes it rely on utility and status moves to disrupt foes. It also lacks great defensive stats to constantly check threats such as Regirock.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: U-turn is used to get Whimsicott out of bad matchups, especially after using Switcheroo, when its power is lower. Psychic hits Poison-types very hard, doing massive amounts of damage to Weezing and Golbat, while being a reliable way to hit Fire-types neutrally. Hurricane hits Fire-types harder, 2HKOing Centiskorch and usually 2HKOing offensive Charizard, but is much less reliable than Psychic. Switcheroo is used to disrupt defensive cores, as Whimsicott can force in a Pokemon such as Charizard or Togedemaru that would otherwise wall it and limit the Pokemon's counterplay by giving it Choice Specs. Pixie Plate is an alternative to Choice Specs that sacrifices strength for flexibility, making prediction less of a factor. Whimsicott offensively pairs well with Pokemon that break Fire- and Steel-types, most notably Fighting-type Pokemon that can run Rock-type coverage such as Hitmontop and Sawk. Defensively, it appreciates support from Steel-types such as Aggron and Togedemaru to switch into Poison-, Flying-, and Ice-type moves, as well as a bulky Water-types such as Jellicent and Lanturn to handle Fire- and Steel-types. With U-turn, Whimsicott can form a solid VoltTurn core with the latter partner.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description: Knock Off allows Whimsicott to remove important items such as Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots from defensive Pokemon such as Aromatisse and Charizard, making them much less effective at checking offensive threats, while Prankster Encore deals with offensive Pokemon such as Silvally-Ghost and Frosmoth by locking them into a setup move. U-turn is a crucial move for this set, allowing Whimsicott to let wallbreakers such as Lycanroc and Aggron in on its answers like Charizard and Togedemaru, respectively. Stun Spore provides speed control against fast Pokemon such as Ribombee on the switch so that Pokemon such as Scrafty can sweep much more easily. Leech Seed gives Whimsicott a form of recovery, allowing it to exploit defensive Pokemon to increase its longevity. Whimsicott pairs very well with Pokemon that like its usual Steel-, Fire-, and Flying-type switch-ins crippled, such as Frosmoth and Scyther.

sets.name: SubSeed
sets.description: This set uses Prankster to its fullest potential, catching opposing Pokemon with a Leech Seed and then using Substitute before they can act. The combination of Leftovers and Leech Seed recovery almost makes up for the HP loss of using Substitute every turn, slowly draining the opposing Pokemon's HP until it's in range of a Moonblast. Psychic can be used to annoy Poison-types that can easily break its Substitute, while Knock Off is used to disrupt defensive Pokemon with recovery that can stall Leech Seed. Encore can be used to prevent setup Pokemon such as Ribombee from taking advantage of this set's passive nature while also stalling out the recovery of defensive Pokemon such as Palossand. This set struggles most against Grass-types such as Tangela and Ferroseed, and Whimsicott must be wary of moves such as Dual Wingbeat from Archeops and Scyther that both break its Substitute and damage it. Defensively, Whimsicott needs Pokemon such as Aggron and Stunfisk-Galar that can tank hits from Pokemon that can get past its Substitute, and these teammates can also benefit from the passive recovery that Leech Seed gives them. It also benefits from Flying- and Fire-types such as Charizard and Magmortar that deal with the Grass-types it struggles against.

Lilligant.overview: Despite being seemingly outclassed by Ribombee as a Quiver Dance sweeper, two things set Lilligant apart: Sleep Powder and Nature Power. Sleep Powder allows Lilligant to safely set up against slower Pokemon that would otherwise beat it like Weezing and Togedemaru. The second is Nature Power, which transforms into Tri Attack under normal circumstances, giving Lilligant a strong attack to break past many Grass-resistant Pokemon like Charizard and Druddigon more easily, and Nature Power is easier to run on Lilligant than Ribombee due to the latter's need for Aromatherapy and Roost. This, combined with Lilligant not being forced to run Heavy-Duty Boots, lets it serve as a solid sweeper. However, Lilligant can be wildly inconsistent, as it relies on sleep turns to break past many of its switch-ins. Its lack of coverage also leaves it walled by Steel-types such as Togedemaru, which is troublesome if it does not get adequate Sleep turns or if Lilligant has already put a foe to sleep. Without a Speed boost, it is easily revenge killed by Pokemon like Silvally-Ghost, and even at +1, it is outsped by Choice Scarf Togedemaru and has to play a guessing game versus Ninjask. Finally, Lilligant's paltry bulk belies its decent defensive typing, and as such, Lilligant provides less defensive utility compared to other sweepers like Ribombee.

sets.name: Quiver Dance
sets.description: Giga Drain is a decently powerful STAB move that heals chip damage Lilligant tends to take from entry hazards, sand, and weak attacks. Petal Dance, when combined with Own Tempo, gives Lilligant more power in exchange for giving it less sustainability. Chlorophyll bolsters Lilligant's matchup against sun teams, which are uncommon but can be annoying to deal with offensively. Lilligant dislikes opposing Steel-types such as Ferroseed and Perrserker; Togedemaru in particular is troublesome due to its access to consistent recovery, ability to pivot into an offense check, and propensity to cripple Lilligant with Toxic, so Pokemon that can break past them such as Charizard and Hitmontop are appreciated teammates. Ribombee also makes for an excellent partner, as together they can wear down each other's checks, such as Centiskorch, and open up sweeping opportunities for each other. Lilligant can hit a shared check with Sleep Powder, while Ribombee can heal annoying status from Togedemaru and Regirock with Aromatherapy. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Froslass can help wear down Lilligant's switch-ins.

Basculin.overview: Utilizing Adaptability and its good Speed tier, Basculin is a good offensive threat in the metagame, being able to function as both a strong physical and special wallbreaker and outspeeds common offensive threats such as the Silvally formes. Unfortunately, the tier is full of common Water immunities such as Toxicroak and Heliolisk, which prevent Basculin from spamming its STAB moves frequently; outside of using its STAB moves, Basculin lacks in damage output. While it takes a bit of support to use, once the Water immunities are dealt with, Basculin can use its high damage output to wallbreak efficiently.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description: Superpower is Basculin's preferred coverage option in order to deal with certain Water-resistant and Water-immune Pokemon like Heliolisk and Guzzlord. Psychic Fangs is used to hit Toxicroak and Qwilfish, two Pokemon that otherwise wall Basculin, but Aqua Jet can instead be used to revenge kill faster threats such as Archeops. Ice Beam is another alternative to hit opposing Grass-types like Tangela and Alolan Exeggutor. Basculin appreciates partners that are able to deal with Jellicent, which shuts down Basculin. Heliolisk is a great example, and it appreciates Basculin's ability to deal with special walls like Gigalith and Assault Vest Guzzlord. Basculin also struggles with Pokemon like Toxicroak and Tangela depending on what coverage move it opts to use, so teammates like Charizard and Garbodor are greatly appreciated. Basculin welcomes entry hazard support from Pokemon like Ferroseed and Mesprit, which enables it to increase its wallbreaking capabilities. Mesprit, in addition to the aforementioned Heliolisk, can also form a VoltTurn core with Basculin, giving Basculin additional opportunities to come onto the field safely. Mesprit in particular also offers Healing Wish support to increase Basculin's longevity.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Ice Beam is Basculin's best coverage option, allowing it to hit opposing Dragon- and Grass-type Pokemon such as Silvally-Dragon and Tsareena, as well as certain Water-immune Pokemon like Toxicroak and Heliolisk for good damage. Flip Turn lets Basculin get free damage on its incoming switch-ins like Lanturn while maintaining offensive momentum, which helps its teammates. Toxic is essential to cripple Jellicent and Lanturn. However, locking into Toxic has its drawbacks of forcing Basculin out versus Steel- and Poison-types like Togedemaru and Toxicroak. Defensive partners like Assault Vest Guzzlord are nice to handle the strong Electric-types in the tier like Heliolisk and Rotom, and it punishes incoming switch-ins with Knock Off chip damage, which is vital for Basculin to secure KOs.

Scrafty.overview: Scrafty can be run as an either bulky or fast setup sweeper, sporting both Bulk Up and Dragon Dance. Its solid bulk and defensive typing give it various opportunities to switch in against and set up on Pokemon such as Weezing and Palossand. However, this same typing also gives it weaknesses to common types such as Fairy and Fighting, which are often run as coverage on Pokemon Scrafty wants to check such as Mesprit and Absol. Scrafty's typing also has its ups and downs offensively, as it is able to hit most of the tier neutrally, but Fairy-types such as Aromatisse and Silvally-Fairy completely wall it if it is not running coverage. While Scrafty's defenses are good, its Attack is underwhelming without boosts and its Speed is very mediocre, with it still being outsped even at +1 by Pokemon such as Ribombee and Whimsicott.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description: This set allows Scrafty to serve as a special sponge that can soft check special attackers such as Rotom, which it can use as setup fodder. This pairs well with Bulk Up because, after setting up, Scrafty can take both physical and special hits, ideally allowing it to slowly break through the opponent's remaining Pokemon. This is furthered by its combination of Rest and Shed Skin, which makes Scrafty harder to wear down and cripple with status conditions, although Shed Skin can be unreliable at times. Drain Punch also helps keep Scrafty healthy, while Knock Off does decent damage while crippling Pokemon that may depend on their items such as Ribombee and Whimsicott. Scrafty prefers to start setting up after threats to it such as Whimsicott and Aromatisse have been taken out, so Pokemon that can help against those such as Uxie, Togedemaru, and Rotom make for good teammates.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Dragon Dance gives Scrafty a greater offensive presence, with Moxie giving it an easier time sweeping and maximum Speed with a Jolly nature allowing it to outspeed base 110 Speed Pokemon after one Dragon Dance. Close Combat serves as its powerful STAB move, although High Jump Kick is slightly more powerful and has no defense drops in exchange for considerably more risk. Iron Head hits Fairy-types like Silvally-Fairy and Aromatisse. Lum Berry gives Scrafty one-time protection from status conditions that would otherwise make it much harder to sweep, but Chople Berry can instead be used to take moves such as Mach Punch from Hitmontop, and ease setup against Body Press users such as Regirock. Shed Skin can be run if using a Chople Berry so Scrafty can still set up against status inflicting Pokemon like Jellicent. Good teammates are Pokemon that can help against faster threats such as Ribombee and priority users like the previously mentioned Hitmontop. Both Togedemaru and Silvally-Fairy make for good teammates, as they can check these threats and bring Scrafty onto the field with their respective pivoting moves. Wallbreakers like Magmortar and Vikavolt can weaken bulky Pokemon such as Weezing and Aromatisse, making it easier for Scrafty to clean up the match.

Cofagrigus.overview: Cofagrigus sets itself apart from other Ghost-types through its useful supportive and defensive capabilities. Because of its access to Toxic Spikes, Cofagrigus can aid its teammates by wearing down their checks while doing the same to its own checks, such as Palossand and Jellicent. Its Ghost typing and bulk are useful for denying Rapid Spin from Pokemon such as Tsareena and Hitmontop, and Iron Defense + Body Press pressures these Pokemon further, notably OHKOing Alolan Sandslash. This combination of moves is also useful late-game once Cofagrigus's checks have been worn down, making it a valuable asset throughout a game. However, Cofagrigus has a serious lack of reliable recovery and is forced to rely on Rest, rendering it setup fodder for Pokemon such as Nasty Plot Mesprit and Quiver Dance Ribombee. It also has lackluster Special Defense, which lets wallbreakers such as Vikavolt and Magmortar easily pierce through it.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Shadow Ball is an interesting alternative over Toxic Spikes to hit Ghost-types, which otherwise wall Cofagrigus. Notably, this includes Rotom, Heavy-Duty Boots Froslass, and opposing Cofagrigus, which are not heavily impacted by Toxic Spikes. However, the supportive capabilities of Toxic Spikes are generally preferred due to these Pokemon being uncommon, and Toxic Spikes is more useful during the early- and mid-game stages. Despite Chesto Berry usually being run to give Cofagrigus a one-time instant recovery option alongside Rest, running no item makes it harder to pressure with Poltergeist and Knock Off users such as Froslass, Gourgeist-S, and Absol. The Speed investment lets it outspeed Galarian Stunfisk, and the remaining EVs combined with a Bold nature bolster Cofagrigus's physical bulk, which improves its durability and the damage output of Body Press. Alternatively, a specially defensive spread of 248 HP / 240 SpD / 20 Spe with a Calm nature allows it to take special hits better at the cost of its physical bulk and attacking power. Cofagrigus should be paired with Pokemon that can cover for it against special attackers; these include blanket special walls such as Gigalith and Lanturn. These examples also benefit from Toxic Spikes pressuring checks like Jellicent and Quagsire. Offensive partners such as Tsareena and Choice Scarf Togedemaru appreciate Cofagrigus's Toxic Spikes, and, in return, both can safely pivot into Cofagrigus. Tsareena can also remove entry hazards on its side and Heavy-Duty Boots from foes for Cofagrigus with Rapid Spin and Knock Off, respectively. Cofagrigus also appreciates Pokemon that can threaten grounded Poison-types, as they remove Toxic Spikes; this includes Charizard, Mesprit, and Sandaconda.

Archeops.overview: Archeops is a very threatening Pokemon in the PU tier thanks to its fantastic offensive stats, vivid movepool, and great Speed tier. Earthquake and Stone Edge give Archeops near-perfect coverage that leaves its switch-ins restricted to a marginal few, such as Claydol, Palossand, and Regirock. Archeops also has a decent defensive typing, allowing it to check foes like Charizard in a pinch; however, it is held back by its poor defensive stats. It doesn't want to be the sole defensive switch-in to any foe, preferring to pivot in on resisted attacks such as Centiskorch's Fire Lash. Defeatist is a dreadful ability that basically makes Archeops useless if it drops below 50%, further hindering its ability to hard switch into foes like Scyther well and making it very dependent on both Heavy-Duty Boots and Roost.

sets.name: Heavy-Duty Boots
sets.description: U-turn is the preferred option in the third slot to generate momentum against foes like Palossand. Dual Wingbeat is an option that lets Archeops OHKO Sturdy Sawk and revenge kill other Grass- and Fighting-types, like Tsareena and Gallade, more reliably. Roost is necessary to offset HP loss that activates Defeatist. Heavy-Duty Boots is another important tool that prevents Archeops's Stealth Rock weakness from wearing it down into Defeatist range. Archeops fits best on offensive teams, and it should primarily be brought in via safe switches in to wallbreak or revenge kill threats such as Galarian Articuno and Magmortar, as its lack of defensive utility prevents it from getting many free turns otherwise. For this reason, partners with pivoting moves like Ribombee and Whimsicott work well with Archeops, and they form a pivot core if Archeops is using U-turn. Lanturn is another partner that can bring Archeops in safely, and it can absorb both Water- and Electric-type attacks aimed at Archeops as well as provide an additional check to Togedemaru. Froslass can help pressure many of Archeops's checks, like Palossand and Rhydon thanks to its access to Spikes, notably bringing walls like Jellicent into 2HKO range of Stone Edge. Pokemon like Sneasel and Choice Specs Ribombee are problematic foes for Archeops, as they are faster and threaten to KO it, so Ferroseed and Choice Scarf Togedemaru can help pressure them.

sets.name: Suicide Lead
sets.description: Archeops is a good Stealth Rock setter on hyper offense teams. Its high Speed tier lets it block opposing entry hazard setters with Taunt, and it can KO itself with Head Smash to bring a teammate in safely and prevent Rapid Spin and Defog from removing its hazards. Focus Sash ensures that it can almost always set Stealth Rock; however, once it is brought into Defeatist range, there isn't too much value in preserving Archeops. Archeops can pretty much support every offensive threat in the tier, and it should almost always be the lead on the hyper offense teams it is used on. Nasty Plot Mesprit and Swords Dance Silvally-Fairy are offensive threats that appreciate the support Archeops provides. Galarian Articuno can punish Defog attempts with Competitive, letting it become more dangerous even if Stealth Rock gets removed. Offensive checks to Sneasel such as Ribombee are helpful because it can prevent Stealth Rock from being set with Triple Axel, assuming it lands two hits. Many of the aforementioned Pokemon can also bring Archeops in safely with U-turn to find opportunities to set Stealth Rock if it was unable to earlier on.

Gothitelle.overview: The following analysis was written in a prior iteration of the PU metagame and as a result does not accurately reflect the current state of the tier, where Gothitelle is considered outclassed and not worth using. This page will be updated later to reflect this.

sets.name: Cosmic Power + Stored Power
sets.description:
Gothitelle faces competition from other Psychic-types like Musharna, Mr. Rime, and Beheeyem, with these Pokemon fitting onto multiple teams more easily. This is because of them being more potent offensively, more reliably checking Throh, having reliable recovery, and generating momentum in Beheeyem's case. In spite of this, Gothitelle can still function as a solid bulky setup sweeper due to its decent bulk with investment, Cosmic Power further augmenting its defenses, and Stored Power allowing it to make excellent use of the boosts it accrues. Teams lacking Dark-types can struggle with Gothitelle, since even specially bulky Pokemon and Psychic-resistant Pokemon, such as Dusclops, Type: Null, and Silvally-Psychic, take too much damage after enough boosts. Stored Power also bypasses Pyukumuku's Unaware, meaning Gothitelle can be a major threat to stall teams. Leftovers lessens the need to use Rest and provides Gothitelle with passive recovery, while Colbur Berry reduces the damage that it takes from Dark-type coverage against foes like Grapploct. Competitive exploits moves and abilities that drop Gothitelle's stats, like Defog and Intimidate, by boosting its Special Attack and making Stored Power stronger. Moves like Mean Look and Thunderbolt can be used over Sleep Talk to trap and set up on passive foes or hit Dark-types, respectively, though forgoing Sleep Talk leaves Gothitelle completely helpless while it's asleep. Weakness Policy allows Gothitelle to take advantage of super effective coverage like Knock Off from Throh and U-turn from non-Swords Dance Silvally formes. This is an especially viable option, since most opponents will go for super effective moves against Gothitelle given its bulk.

Gothitelle fits best on bulkier builds, since its defensive nature and relatively low Speed would cost more offensive teams too much momentum. Dark-types like Pawniard and Galarian Linoone completely wall Gothitelle if its only attacking move is Stored Power. Fighting-types like Hitmontop and Throh are important teammates to have because of this, with the former also removing entry hazards with Rapid Spin and the latter wearing teams down through the combination of Circle Throw and Knock Off. Strong attackers like Silvally-Bug, Choice Specs Glaceon, and Nasty Plot Raichu can overwhelm Gothitelle faster than it can boost, meaning that teammates to pressure these wallbreakers, like Lapras and Roselia, are appreciated. Roselia can also pressure opposing teams with Spikes and Toxic Spikes, making it easier for Gothitelle to sweep. Silvally formes like Silvally-Bug and Silvally-Electric can also be useful partners, providing support through blocking Trick and Switcheroo from Mr. Mime and Manectric, breaking through foes like Mawile, and potentially removing entry hazards with Defog. In return, Gothitelle can absorb status conditions and set up on potential revenge killers like Manectric locked into Overheat. Pairing Gothitelle with Dark-types, notably Taunt Pawniard, can prevent a potential stalemate against opposing bulky Stored Power users like Musharna and Duosion.

Jellicent.overview: Jellicent is one of the best defensive Water-types in the tier. Compared to its primary competitor in Lanturn, however, Jellicent brings to the table an excellent Ghost typing further enhanced by its myriad of supportive options such as Will-O-Wisp, Taunt, and Recover. Because of this, Jellicent is an effective switch-in to Fighting-types like Hitmontop as well as an excellent defensive check to various physical attackers such as Kabutops and Alolan Sandslash. Jellicent also provides teams additional utility by punishing Water-types or Choice-locked attackers depending on if it's running Water Absorb or Cursed Body. However, Jellicent can be rather passive due to its low offensive capabilities and reliance on status as the typical way of dealing damage. Furthermore, Jellicent struggles versus common special attackers such as Whimsicott and Vikavolt, as many of them can comfortably switch in and typically are not overly bothered by Will-O-Wisp or Toxic.

sets.name: Defensive Utility
sets.description: Will-O-Wisp is the preferred status move as a way to catch many physical attackers that threaten Jellicent such as Tsareena, Absol, Togedemaru, and Gourgeist; however, Toxic can be used here in order to better cripple bulkier checks such as Lanturn and opposing Jellicent. Hex is preferred as the sole attacking move on this set because it pairs well with its status moves versus bulkier defensive answers such as Lanturn. Colbur Berry is the optimal item in order to weaken Knock Off from the likes of Sneasel or Gallade, but Heavy-Duty Boots can be used in order to be immune to entry hazards. Jellicent can also opt to not use an item, allowing it to switch into Choice Band Froslass, at the cost of some defensive utility against other threats. Gigalith makes a fantastic partner for Jellicent, as not only is it a good check to special attackers like Haunter, but with Sand Stream and hazard support, the residual damage Jellicent can spread with Will-O-Wisp and Toxic can severely cripple offensive answers like Whimsicott and Vikavolt. Conversely, Gigalith appreciates Jellicent's ability to reliably provide a Fighting immunity versus Choice-locked attackers like Sawk. Silvally-Fairy is also a fine partner, since it acts as a Knock Off absorber if Jellicent isn't running Colbur Berry and handles Dark-types such as Absol. Whimsicott makes a great offensive partner for Jellicent thanks to its ability to offensively check Sandaconda, Scrafty, and Absol, whereas Jellicent can check Charizard decently well. 32 Speed EVs allow Jellicent to outspeed Carracosta and Taunt it, preventing it from setting up with Shell Smash.

Galvantula.overview: Due to its great Speed, good offensive typing and coverage, and ability to threaten common entry hazard removers like Charizard, Tsareena, and Golbat, Galvantula is an effective Sticky Web setter. Its access to Volt Switch in combination with these traits also makes it a decent pivot. However, Galvantula's meager Special Attack hinders its overall damage output. Opting for Life Orb does make up for this, particularly if Galvantula runs Thunder, but doing so means forgoing Heavy-Duty Boots and limiting its staying power. Galvantula also faces competition from other Sticky Web setters in Ribombee and Vikavolt. The former is better against Pokemon like Whimsicott due to its higher Speed, while the latter is much stronger, has Levitate and better bulk, and possesses similar coverage.

sets.name: Offensive Support
sets.description: Thunder is Galvantula's strongest STAB move and doesn't force it to switch out like Volt Switch does. The move's accuracy is also boosted by Compound Eyes, substantially increasing its reliability. Energy Ball can be used instead to put more pressure on Rock- and Ground-types like Regirock and Palossand. Heavy-Duty Boots negates the effects of entry hazards, giving Galvantula an easier time switching around and annoying offensive teams. Alternatively, Life Orb can be used to bolster Galvantula's offensive presence, giving it a high chance to OHKO Pokemon like defensive Mesprit with Bug Buzz after Stealth Rock. However, losing immunity to entry hazards and taking Life Orb recoil both decrease its overall longevity. Slower wallbreakers and setup sweepers like Haunter and Nasty Plot Rotom-F very much appreciate Galvantula both slowing down potential revenge killers, like Basculin, with Sticky Web and generating momentum for them with Volt Switch. Both of these Pokemon also benefit from Galvantula's ability to force damage onto shared checks like Gigalith and Lanturn, and can break through bulkier walls like Sandaconda and Palossand in return. Rapid Spin users like Tsareena and Hitmontop can give Galvantula's teammates easier entry without removing Sticky Web and offensively check Pokemon such as Palossand and Charizard, with Tsareena in particular also maintaining momentum with U-turn. Support from the previously mentioned spinners can also allow Galvantula to more comfortably use Life Orb.

Ferroseed.overview: With its typing, Eviolite-boosted bulk, and access to Spikes and Stealth Rock, Ferroseed functions as an effective entry hazard setter and good blanket check to several offensive and defensive threats, including Ribombee, non-Trick Mesprit, Gigalith, and Aromatisse. These same traits alongside Iron Barbs allow Ferroseed to annoy pivots such as Togedemaru and removers like non-High Jump Kick Tsareena and Alolan Sandslash. Despite lacking reliable recovery, Leech Seed and Ferroseed's natural immunity to Toxic and chip damage from sand can make it incredibly hard for some teams to wear down. However, prominent Pokemon like Charizard and Scrafty pressure Ferroseed with their STAB moves due to its typing. Ferroseed's passivity also leaves it unable to do much in the face of setup sweepers like the aforementioned Scrafty, Sandaconda, and Cofagrigus. Finally, Ferroseed must exercise caution around foes like Tsareena, Aggron, and Mesprit, since they can punish it for recklessly switching in with either super effective coverage or moves like Knock Off and Trick.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Stealth Rock can be considered over Spikes to save a slot on Ferroseed's team and pressure non-grounded foes like Levitate Weezing, but Spikes tends to be more useful for reliably wearing down grounded Pokemon like Gigalith, Sandaconda, and Jellicent. Protect provides Ferroseed with additional recovery from Leech Seed and lets it scout Choice-locked foes like Sawk and Pokemon like Tsareena, which may have super effective coverage. Running a Relaxed nature and no Speed IVs maximizes the damage output of Gyro Ball, which compensates for Ferroseed's passivity. Try not to immediately use Gyro Ball too much, though, as the move has limited PP. Knock Off is an alternative utility option that punishes Charizard on the switch as well as other foes looking to take advantage of Ferroseed's passivity. However, it can be difficult to make room for, since Ferroseed's other moves are incredibly useful. Gigalith is a great partner, covering for Ferroseed's weakness to Fire, completing an entry hazard stacking core with it, and using sand to give it an even easier time wearing foes down. In return, Ferroseed switches into Water-types like Lanturn and Wishiwashi and can make up for its lack of recovery with Leech Seed. Jellicent can check Fighting-types and block Rapid Spin for Ferroseed, all while suffocating opposing walls with its utility options and Ferroseed's entry hazards. Offensive partners like Silvally-Fairy, Galarian Articuno, and Archeops pressure threats Ferroseed lets in, such as Scrafty and Charizard. These teammates also benefit from their switch-ins being worn down by entry hazards, with Galarian Articuno also punishing Defog attempts with Competitive.

Stunfisk-Galar.overview: Galarian Stunfisk's unique typing and great bulk make it a solid switch-in to attackers like Ribombee, Togedemaru, and Vikavolt, giving it a solid niche over other Ground- and Steel-types like Palossand and Silvally-Steel. It can also further support its team with Stealth Rock and other support moves like Yawn. However, while its typing is at times great, it can also be a hinderance when trying to switch into threats like Frosmoth and Lycanroc that Steel- and Ground-types, respectively, usually check. Its lack of reliable recovery also makes it quite easy to overwhelm.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Rock Slide allows Galarian Stunfisk to beat Bug- and Flying-types like Ribombee and Archeops more reliably, although Stone Edge can also be used to always knock Archeops into Defeatist range. Yawn prevents Pokemon like Tsareena and Palossand from freely switching into Galarian Stunfisk, while Pain Split gives it a mean of recovery, albeit unreliable. Aromatisse makes for a stellar partner thanks to ability to switch into threats like Scrafty for Galarian Stunfisk; it can also heal it back up with Wish, which it greatly appreciates. In return, Galarian Stunfisk checks Steel-types like Togedemaru and Silvally-Steel for Aromatisse. Similarly, Weezing and Silvally-Fairy can take on Fighting-types such as Hitmontop that it struggles against. Lastly, wallbreakers and setup sweepers like Trevenant and Quiver Dance Ribombee appreciate Galarian Stunfisk providing them with more opportunities to come in via Yawn.

Druddigon.overview: Druddigon makes an effective pivot with its Dragon typing and ability in Rough Skin, which is used in conjunction with Rocky Helmet to punish U-turn and Flip Turn users like Togedemaru and Basculin. Heavy Defense investment lets it switch into notable Pokemon such as Tsareena and Togedemaru. Druddigon also has a great supportive movepool with access to Stealth Rock and Glare. However, Druddigon is weak to common Fairy- and Ice-type attacks from Pokemon like Ribombee and Froslass, as well as lacking any reliable recovery options.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Dragon Tail can be used to phaze Pokemon and rack up damage with Stealth Rock against Defoggers such as Charizard or setup sweepers such as Cosmic Power Claydol. Otherwise, Dragon Claw makes a decent alternative. Glare is used to spread paralysis, mainly targeting Whimsicott and Ribombee that may try to switch into Druddigon. Earthquake provides good coverage with Dragon Tail, hitting Steel-types like Aggron and Togedemaru super effectively. Endure can be used as a way to accumulate an extra turn of Rocky Helmet and Rough Skin damage onto a foe, which can help check opposing Pokemon such as Triple Axel Froslass in a pinch. Leftovers can be used as an alternative to Rocky Helmet to provide Druddigon with more longevity. Silvally-Fairy and other fast wallbreakers pair well with Druddigon, as Druddigon can punish fast Pokemon like Togedemaru that attempt to revenge kill them. Aggron and Charizard help to cover Fairy-types like Aromatisse and Ribombee that attempt to take advantage of Druddigon. Togedemaru is another Fairy-resistant Pokemon that can provide Wish support, which helps Druddigon stay healthy throughout a game.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Meowstic-F finds a solid niche in PU as a frail, but fast, wallbreaker that threatens common Fighting-, Poison-, and Water-types. Thunderbolt devastates Water-types while serving as Meowstic-F's best method of hitting Dark- and Steel-types such as Pawniard, Thievul, Mawile, and Klang. Protect provides valuable utility, allowing Meowstic-F to block First Impression from Fraxure and Falinks while letting it scout for moves from Choice item users such as Manectric and Stonjourner and gain additional recovery if running Leftovers. Shadow Ball is a notable mention over Protect, allowing Meowstic-F to threaten opposing Psychic-types. Colbur Berry provides a one-time damage reduction against Dark-type moves, allowing Meowstic-F to potentially stay in against Pawniard and Thievul to retaliate with Thunderbolt while also reducing the damage from Throh's Knock Off and Falink's Throat Chop. Leftovers can be utilized over Colbur Berry to offer recovery, extending Meowstic-F's longevity. Competitive, in tandem with its naturally high Speed tier, allows Meowstic-F to outspeed and punish Defog from the various Silvally formes and other slower Defoggers such as Vibrava and Vespiquen.

Fighting-types such as Falinks, Throh, and Hitmontop appreciate Meowstic-F removing Poison-types such as Mareanie, Gloom, and Roselia that limit their effectiveness. In return, they are able to eliminate Dark- and Steel-types such as Pawniard, Thievul, and Klang that trouble Meowstic-F. Steel-types such as Mawile and Pawniard can help Meowstic-F by offering Stealth Rock support, wearing down opposing foes, and by serving as soft checks to Bug-types like Crustle and Silvally-Bug. Setup sweepers such as Klang, Eiscue, and Thievul can benefit from Meowstic-F removing Fighting-types, letting them set up and sweep late-game. Entry hazard setters such as Crustle and Roselia appreciate Meowstic-F's ability to punish Defog from Silvally formes to reliably get up their hazards, providing valuable residual damage that can make up for Meowstic-F's mediocre Special Attack stat.

Aromatisse.overview: Aromatisse is one of the best defensive Fairy-types in the tier, capable of checking powerful Fighting-types like Scrafty. Aromatisse sets itself apart from its competition thanks to the Wish and Heal Bell support it can provide its teammates, as well as an immunity to Taunt and Encore. Unfortunately, Aromatisse's mono-Fairy typing, poor Special Attack stat and lack of coverage leave it prone to giving strong wallbreakers like Magmortar and Aggron a free switch-in. Aromatisse is reliant on Wish to keep itself healthy, forcing it to use Protect very often, which can be a huge momentum drain. Aromatisse faces little direct competition but teams that do not need its Wish support may wish to invest in a Fighting-type check with more utility, such as Weezing.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Heal Bell provides Aromatisse and its teammates with cleric support. Toxic allows Aromatisse to cripple Pokemon like Gigalith and Charizard. Calm Mind is an option for the last slot to give Aromatisse a more offensive precense; however, many Fairy-resistant Pokemon such as Centiskorch and Aggron can overwhelm Aromatisse with sheer power. Aroma Veil is a useful ability that prevents Aromatisse from being shut down by Taunt and Encore. Heavy-Duty Boots is an alternative option over Leftovers to prevent Aromatisse from being worn down by entry hazards, though the passive recovery from Leftovers is generally preferred.

Aromatisse fits best on bulky offense and balance builds that value Wish support and a sturdy Fighting-type check. Synthesis variants of Tsareena can wear down Ferroseed, a Pokemon which heavily abuses Aromatisse's passivity, and also provides Rapid Spin support to stop Aromatisse from being easily worn down by entry hazards. In return, Aromatisse can cleanse Tsareena of status and give it easier entry with Wish support. Weezing and Jellicent can help provide a secondary Fighting-type check, better handling Triple Axel Hitmontop, and can check offensive breakers like Aggron and Swords Dance Qwilfish, respectively. Gigalith and Lanturn can help check strong Fire-types such as Magmortar and Charizard that Aromatisse invites in, both also greatly valuing the Wish support Aromatisse provides.

Trevenant.overview: Trevenant is one of PU's most devastating wallbreakers because of its high Attack, amazing offensive typing, and powerful STAB moves in Poltergeist and Wood Hammer. Trevenant also has some useful defensive attributes that differentiate it from other offensive Ghost-types such as Gourgeist-S and Froslass. Chief among these qualities is Natural Cure, which allows it to more comfortably switch into status inducers like Quagsire and Glare Sandaconda. Furthermore, Trevenant can heal while attacking with Horn Leech, which isn't weather-dependent like Synthesis, and isn't weak to Stealth Rock like Froslass. However, Trevenant lacks the bulk and longevity necessary to make full use of these good traits. While it outspeeds most defensive Pokemon, Trevenant is still incredibly slow, which, combined with its frailty and poor defensive typing, makes it easy to pressure and limits its opportunities to safely switch in. Trevenant also faces competition as a Ghost-type wallbreaker from Gourgeist-S and Froslass, since both are faster, the former is more versatile with moves like Explosion and Flame Charge, and the latter offers vital utility in Spikes.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Earthquake lets Trevenant OHKO Aggron and 2HKO itemless Neutralizing Gas Weezing. Alternatively, Drain Punch hits Ghost-immune Sap Sipper users like Drampa and Miltank harder. Trick can be used to annoy defensive Pokemon like Tangela and virtually guarantee that a foe can be hit by Poltergeist, although Trevenant becomes noticeably weaker without Choice Band. Sucker Punch is another option that allows Trevenant to make up for its lackluster Speed, but it's prediction-reliant and not a good move to be locked into. While Frisk lets Trevenant scout for items and whether foes can be hit by Poltergeist, not being rendered useless by status thanks to Natural Cure is usually more useful. Using an Adamant nature maximizes Trevenant's damage output, but opting for a Jolly nature allows it to outspeed Pokemon like Jolly Aggron and Perrserker. Despite being incredibly strong, Trevenant can still struggle to take care of some physical walls like Tangela. Therefore, powerful special attackers such as Galarian Articuno and Charizard are good teammates. The former can also use U-turn to get Trevenant in safely and put immense pressure on Trevenant's answers with Future Sight, while the latter can remove entry hazards with Defog. Entry hazard support helps to wear down annoying physical walls too. In particular, Spikes setters like Alolan Sandslash can be incredibly useful, helping Trevenant guarantee 2HKOs against Pokemon like Ferroseed with Poltergeist. Avoid pairing Trevenant with Knock Off users, since they'll prevent it from as freely using Poltergeist.

Vikavolt.overview: Vikavolt is a wallbreaking powerhouse, sporting a massive base 145 Special Attack stat, powerful STAB attacks, Volt Switch, and decent coverage to boot. It can also switch into threats like Palossand and Passimian thanks to its passable bulk, typing, and access to recovery. However, Vikavolt is very slow for a wallbreaker, and its Bug typing can be a hindrance, as it leaves Vikavolt unable to switch into Pokemon like Regirock that it can otherwise easily pressure. It is often outclassed by Ribombee and Galvantula as a Sticky Web setter, as their Speed tier is much more suited for the aggressive playstyle, with Galvantula also sporting the same typing and Volt Switch. Similarly, Agility sets suffer from competition from Quiver Dance Ribombee.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: This set takes advantage of Vikavolt's wallbreaking potential, forcing out most Pokemon slower than it such as Sandaconda and Jellicent. Although Thunderbolt is a great reliable STAB move for Vikavolt, Sticky Web can be used on more offensive teams as speed control, giving Vikavolt a few more opportunities to outspeed and pressure opposing Pokemon such as Aggron and Adamant Absol but mostly serving to support its teammates. Bug Buzz is primarily used on Vikavolt as a reliable way to hit Pokemon that Electric-type moves cannot hit as well, such as Druddigon and Tsareena. However, Energy Ball is a useful alterative to hit Ground-types harder, such as Palossand and Rhydon, that may attempt to block Volt Switch. A good partner for this set is Passimian, which can assist in offensively checking common switch-ins such as Gigalith and Regirock and deter the opponent from using Defog thanks to Defiant. It can also form a solid VoltTurn core with Vikavolt. Other wallbreakers that appreciate the Sticky Web support like Magmortar and Silvally-Steel make for solid partners. The former appreciates Vikavolt taking on Water-types such as Lanturn, while the latter can pressure defensive behemoths like Gigalith for Vikavolt.

sets.name: Agility
sets.description: This set uses Vikavolt's wallbreaking potential and transforms it into a late-game sweeper, using Agility to make it faster than the entirety of the unboosted metagame. Vikavolt's natural bulk and typing let it use Agility against Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Passimian and Togedemaru as well as more defensive Pokemon that struggle to damage it such as Uxie and Claydol. Energy Ball is used to defeat Pokemon that resist its primary attacks, such as Palossand and Galarian Stunfisk. Roost, however, can give Vikavolt more longevity, allowing it to recover on more defensive threats to make it harder to revenge kill. This set pairs well with entry hazards setters such as Spikes Froslass and Qwilfish, as these help Vikavolt force its way past difficult-to-break Pokemon such as Gigalith and specially defensive Togedemaru. It also defensively pairs well with Ground-types such as Palossand and Sandaconda that resist Rock-type attacks from Pokemon such as Lycanroc and Regirock, since these Pokemon often stop Vikavolt from sweeping.

Ribombee.overview: Ribombee makes for an incredibly versatile threat due to its blistering Speed, good typing, and solid movepool. These traits render it capable of fulfilling multiple roles, ranging from an offensive pivot able to support its teammates with Sticky Web to a capable wallbreaker and cleaner with Choice Specs and Quiver Dance, respectively. It can also revenge kill various threats like Sneasel and Archeops. However, Ribombee struggles a lot against Steel- and Fire-types as well as specially defensive walls like Aggron, Magmortar, and Gigalith due to its average Special Attack and relative lack of coverage options.

sets.name: Quiver Dance
sets.description: Thanks to its decent coverage and great Speed, Ribombee makes for a fairly threatening setup sweeper. Roost allows Ribombee to use walls like non-Toxic Palossand as setup fodder and makes Ribombee a far more reliable answer to Scrafty. Bug Buzz hits Psychic- and Grass-types like Mesprit and Tsareena without needing a boost, while U-turn gives Ribombee more utility early- and mid-game when its checks are still healthy. Wallbreakers like Mesprit and Trevenant are vital partners; they soften up Pokemon like Gigalith, Aggron, and Charizard, making Ribombee much more of a nuisance. Due to its poor bulk, teammates that can bring Ribombee in safely like Lanturn and Togedemaru make for stellar partners; the former can also switch into Fire-types such as Charizard. Lastly, other cleaners like Scrafty and Hitmonlee can set up on Ribombee's answers, and vice versa.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Ribombee's coverage and Speed make it a potent wallbreaker and revenge killer when wielding a Choice Specs. Sticky Web is an option over U-turn for Ribombee to support its teammates, while Switcheroo lets it cripple answers like Gigalith and Togedemaru. However, U-turn is the preferred option due to it easing prediction. Cleaners like Sneasel and Gourgeist-Small appreciate Ribombee weakening walls like Weezing and Aggron for them. Scrafty is another great teammate, as it can also take advantage of some of the various walls that Ribombee finds itself unable to break, such as specially defensive Togedemaru. Stealth Rock and other entry hazards are a huge nuisance to this particular set; they heavily dent Ribombee and make it easier to pick off with a priority move, meaning it has a harder time revenge killing Pokemon like Sneasel and Absol. This makes entry hazard control absolutely vital, with Charizard and Tsareena standing out as great options because they also deal with threats Ribombee struggles against.

sets.name: Offensive Support
sets.description: This set makes Ribombee a capable offensive pivot capable of supporting its teammates with Sticky Web. Stun Spore allows Ribombee to cripple threats it struggles against, like Charizard, while Psychic allows it to hit Poison-types, notably Weezing. U-turn takes advantage of the switches Ribombee forces and allows it to bring it teammates against the Pokemon it invites in. Pokemon like Hitmontop, Magmortar, and Aggron make for fantastic partners; not only do they greatly appreciate Ribombee's Sticky Web, but they can also easily take on threats Ribombee has a hard time against such as Togedemaru and Gigalith. Due to Ribombee's unimpressive damage output, it appreciates Spikes from partners like Froslass, which can pressure Steel-types for Ribombee and also enjoys Ribombee being able to revenge kill or cripple faster threats like Sneasel. Froslass can also switch into Rapid Spin users like Hitmontop trying to get rid of Ribombee's Sticky Web.

Lycanroc.overview: Thanks to its great Speed, great Attack, and coverage, Lycanroc has established itself as a notable offensive threat capable of revenge killing multiple tier staples such as Charizard and Ribombee, which gives it an important niche over Archeops. While it does have a great Attack and movepool, it struggles to get past physically defensive walls that aren't weak to its attacks like Tangela, Quagsire, and Sandaconda without residual damage. Its frailty and poor defensive typing causes it to rely on pivots like Ribombee and Rotom to enter the field safely.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description: With this set, Lycanroc makes for a great revenge killer. Close Combat targets Pokemon like Gigalith, Togedemaru, and Regirock. If running Psychic Fangs, Lycanroc is going to find itself unable to break through Palossand and Claydol; partners that can take them on like Whimsicott and Gourgeist-Small are therefore appreciated.
