They can also weaken other walls such as Weezing in order for Lycanroc to clean. In exchange, they enjoy Lycanroc pressuring Pokemon like Charizard and Sneasel for them. If running Crunch, Lycanroc struggles against Fighting-types such as Hitmontop and Gurdurr, which makes teammates like Jellicent and Aromatisse appreciated. While Life Orb makes Lycanroc less prediction reliant, Choice Band makes it hit considerably harder while also not getting chipped down by Life Orb.

Palossand.overview: Palossand is an important defensive centerpiece in PU thanks to its good typing, bulk, access to Stealth Rock, and ability to check otherwise dangerous Pokemon like Archeops, Lycanroc, and Aggron. It can be very difficult to take down over the course of a game thanks to Shore Up, an excellent reliable recovery move that is often boosted in potency by the common presence that is Gigalith's sand. Its solid STAB coverage and decent Special Attack also make it somewhat difficult to switch into, reducing its passivity. Palossand can struggle somewhat with threats that its typing would otherwise allow it to check, though, like Regirock because of Toxic and Vikavolt because of Energy Ball. It can also be a major momentum drain due to how passive it can be, especially against bulkier teams.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Palossand's great bulk makes it possible for it to come in on foes like Togedemaru, Gigalith, Sawk, and Aggron, giving it ample opportunities to set up Stealth Rock. Colbur Berry provides Palossand with a buffer against Knock Off from the Fighting-types it checks and can also let it check Choice Band Sneasel locked into Knock Off. Checks to strong special attackers like Whimsicott and Ribombee are recommended, since Palossand can't handle them at all. Togedemaru can perform this role while also providing Wish support, which is very helpful, as Palossand can easily be worn down by chip damage from U-turn and entry hazards over longer games. Lanturn provides useful defensive synergy and can further support Palossand with Heal Bell. Other good partners include Weezing, which can act as a good Tsareena check, and Ribombee, which checks annoyances like Scrafty. Both of these Pokemon appreciate Palossand's ability to check Steel-types and set up Stealth Rock to wear down their switch-ins.

Type: Null.overview: The following analysis was written in a prior iteration of the PU metagame and as a result does not accurately reflect the current state of the tier, where Type: Null is considered outclassed and not worth using. This page will be updated later to reflect this.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description: Type: Null's great bulk, which is further bolstered by Eviolite, and access to U-turn make it an incredible pivot able to switch into some of the premier special threats in the tier, like Mr. Rime and Lilligant. U-turn allows Type: Null to pivot out of unfavorable matchups and, thanks to its low Speed, bring a teammate in safely. While Toxic allows Type: Null to cripple Pokemon that try to take advantage of it like Crustle, Stunfisk, and Gourgeist, Crush Claw provides Type: Null with a STAB move that makes it considerably less passive and allows it to beat threats it otherwise wouldn't beat, like Calm Mind Galarian Rapidash. Rest allows it to stay healthy throughout the game and act as a status absorber, while Sleep Talk prevents it from being overly passive when sleeping, although it can be unreliable. Shadow Claw is an option over Toxic or Sleep Talk, as it allows Type: Null to beat Substitute + Calm Mind Drifblim. Answers to Fighting-types, like Drifblim, Qwilfish, and Gourgeist-XL are vital partners, as they can switch into threats like Throh and Falinks that Type: Null struggles against. Drifblim also gets rid of entry hazards, which Type: Null greatly appreciates due to its lack of passive recovery, while Qwilfish sets Spikes and Toxic Spikes. In exchange, Type: Null acts as a reliable switch-in to Pokemon they're threatened by, like Appletun, Beheeyem, and Mr. Rime. Knock Off absorbers, along with Pokemon that can switch into Trick and Switcheroo, are appreciated, since Type: Null needs its item to do its job reliably. Pokemon holding a Rocky Helmet, such as Stunfisk and Runigerus, make for great switch-ins to Knock Off users like Mawile; they can also switch into threats like Perrserker and Silvally-Rock that threaten Type: Null, while they appreciate the latter's ability to switch into Ice-, Grass-, and Water-types. Teammates holding a Choice item like Unfezant and Gourgeist also work, as they can switch into Pokemon with Trick and Switcheroo like Choice Scarf Mr. Mime and Manectric, while they can also revenge kill Pokemon that can overwhelm Type: Null, like Throh. Gourgeist, in particular, can also cripple Pokemon like Calm Mind Musharna and Cosmic Power Gothitelle that Type: Null struggles against with Trick. Strong physical attackers like Choice Band Gourgeist-XL can easily overwhelm Type: Null; this makes answers to these, such as itemless Appletun, great options. They all appreciate Type: Null dealing with special attackers such as Lilligant they struggle against, while they can aid Type: Null in checking Electric-types such as Boltund for Tangela and Manectric in Gourgeist-XL's case. Frailer or slower threats appreciate Type: Null bringing them in safely against Pokemon like Dusknoir, Klinklang, and Stunfisk via U-turn. Choice Band Morpeko, Flame Orb Throh, and Choice Specs Golduck are prime examples, with the former being able to deal with Substitute Calm Mind Drifblim. Lastly, clerics such as Vespiquen and Togetic are appreciated, as Type: Null's reliance on Rest means it can be taken advantage of as well as overwhelmed. They also check Fighting-types like Hitmonchan and appreciate Type: Null dealing with Ice-types like Glaceon.

Silvally-Dark.overview: Silvally-Dark is able to serve as a setup sweeper with its natural bulk and coverage. Its bulk and Speed distinguish it from Absol as a Dark-type wallbreaker, as it is more capable of pulling off a full sweep and is not reliant on Sucker Punch. Silvally-Dark can set up on Choice-locked Mesprit and Jellicent as well as passive Pokemon such as Audino, proceeding to wreak havoc with +2 Multi-Attack allowing Silvally-Dark to muscle past many Pokemon. However, it struggles to compete with the other Silvally formes in both defensive utility and offensive potency due to its typing. Scrafty is another notable Dark-type sweeper that, while slower, is not bothered by status, has access to Knock Off utility, and is much more self sufficient.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Silvally-Dark can break walls other Silvally formes struggle with such as Palossand, Uxie, and Jellicent with its Dark-type Multi-Attack, in addition to generally bulky Pokemon like Gigalith. Iron Head hits common Dark-type answers such as Aromatisse and Whimsicott and can pick off weakened Scrafty. Flame Charge allows Silvally-Dark to clean weakened teams, allowing it to outspeed Pokemon like Lycanroc, Ribombee, and Choice Scarf users like Mesprit. Silvally-Dark greatly appreciates Spikes support to better facilitate a sweep, making Froslass and Ferroseed great partners. Froslass stands out, as it can bait Shadow Ball from Choice Scarf Rotom to give Silvally-Dark a setup opportunity. Poison-types such as Qwilfish and Weezing are able to deal with Fairy-types like Aromatisse and provide additional entry hazards. In return, Silvally-Dark threatens Psychic-types like Mesprit. Special wallbreakers like Galarian Articuno and Ribombee are solid partners to pressure Pokemon such as Regirock and Weezing that Silvally-Dark can't muscle past even after a Swords Dance. They are also able to check Fighting-types such as Gallade and Scrafty. Healing Wish support from Mesprit allows Silvally-Dark to play more aggressively and wear down its own checks while also drawing in Pokemon like Audino and Gigalith.

Silvally-Dragon.overview: With its natural bulk and unique coverage, Silvally-Dragon is able to serve as a consistent setup sweeper. Its typing allows Silvally-Dragon to set up on Pokemon like Tsareena and choice-locked Togedemaru. However, it is unable to provide much defensive utility throughout a match without jeopardizing its ability to sweep. Silvally-Dragon also ends up competing with Silvally-Ghost and -Fairy as a setup sweeper, as these types typically provide more defensive utility and find easier setup opportunities.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Silvally-Dragon is able to muscle through most foes with its STAB Multi-Attack. Iron Head nails Fairy-types like Aromatisse and Whimsicott. Flame Charge allows Silvally-Dragon to hit Steel-types such as Togedemaru and Silvally-Steel harder and outspeed Ribombee, Archeops, and Choice Scarf users like Passimian and Mesprit. With its offensive nature, Silvally-Dragon finds itself most commonly on Spikes stacking offense teams. Silvally-Dragon struggles to get past physically defensive Pokemon like Regirock and Weezing, even after a boost, so it benefits from other wallbreakers like Nasty Plot Mesprit and Quiver Dance Ribombee. Healing Wish support from Mesprit lets Silvally-Dragon be more aggressive and wear down Weezing and Sandaconda without being too bothered by chip damage and potential status. Steel-types like Togedemaru and Aggron deal with opposing Fairy-types, and in return, Silvally-Dragon is able to break past Pokemon like Lanturn and Magmortar.

Silvally-Fairy.overview: Silvally-Fairy is a very versatile threat in the PU metagame thanks to a myriad of factors. Solid base 95 stats across the board and a wide movepool allow it to be easily constructed to fit a specific team's needs. With access to Defog, Parting Shot, and Thunder Wave, it can be a great support Pokemon, while access to Swords Dance and super effective coverage to hit common Fairy-type checks such as Togedemaru and Charizard let it be a great offensive Pokemon. A pure Fairy typing means it's great for checking and setting up on Dark- and Fighting-types such as Absol and Scrafty. Silvally-Fairy's biggest flaw is its lack of any form of recovery. It is also susceptible to all entry hazards and status afflictions, making it easy to wear down and unable to check what it needs to consistently. Finally, it cannot fit all of what it wants on one set, limiting its options.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description: Parting Shot allows Silvally-Fairy to pivot out on would-be threats such as Togedemaru and Aggron. If Defog is unneeded, then Silvally-Fairy can run a status move of its choice to cripple an opposing Pokemon. Despite the Jolly nature, Flamethrower is chosen to hit Steel-types, hitting them harder than Fire Fang. The Speed investment allows Silvally-Fairy to outspeed Timid Magmortar, in addition to slower Pokemon like Absol and Shiftry, and the rest is invested into physical bulk. Notably, it lives a +1 Life Orb Iron Head from Dragon Dance Scrafty with two layers of Spikes up. Silvally-Fairy pairs best with Steel-types, building a solid defensive core with them. Togedemaru is a great option, as it can sponge Poison- and Steel-type attacks while healing Silvally-Fairy with Wish, and, in return, Silvally-Fairy can tank Fighting-type attacks for it. Psychic- and Dark-type attackers such as Mesprit and Scrafty heavily appreciate the absence of Dark- and Fighting-type checks as well as the Parting Shot support, making it easier for them set up without fear of being punished.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: A strong STAB move, great coverage, and two boosting moves let Silvally-Fairy tear through teams. Flame Charge is not only useful for hitting Steel-types, but it lets Silvally-Fairy boost its Speed, making it harder to revenge kill by Choice Scarf users such as Mesprit and Rotom. Rock Slide allows it to OHKO Charizard, while Psychic Fangs is a niche alternative that can take out a weakened Weezing. U-turn is also an option if Silvally-Fairy finds itself in a bad situation, however this means forgoing important coverage. Swords Dance Silvally-Fairy can be used as both a sweeper and a breaker, but be aware that it struggles to break past bulky physically defensive Pokemon such as Regirock and Aggron. Wallbreakers such as Shiftry and Basculin take advantage of these due to their super effective STAB moves while also weakening Fire- and Poison-types, making them solid partners for Silvally-Fairy. Cleaners such as Sneasel and Dragon Dance Charizard also appreciate walls such as Regirock and Palossand being weakened so they can efficiently sweep.

Silvally-Ghost.overview: With access to boosting moves in Swords Dance and Flame Charge alongside a good offensive typing and strong stats, Silvally-Ghost makes for a strong setup sweeper. However, it faces stiff competition from the likes of Silvally-Fairy, which offers teams a stronger defensive typing with a plethora of useful resistances for a setup sweeper whilst maintaining the same coverage, meaning it's much more versatile and can fit on a wider variety of teams. Defensively, it falls short compared to other Ghost-types, such as Palossand and Jellicent, which provide solid secondary typings with useful immunities and greater supportive movepools.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Explosion is outstanding for its ability to provide a one-time nuke versus defensive checks such as Miltank and Scrafty. However, U-turn can be used as a way to gain momentum against the aforementioned Ghost-resists without sacrificing Silvally-Ghost's life in the process. Substitute allows Silvally-Ghost to avoid status from the likes of Lanturn and is a strong option against Sucker Punch users like Absol, but leaves Silvally-Ghost with no way to threaten other bulky Pokemon like Scrafty and Quagsire. Ribombee makes a great partner thanks to its ability to not only offensively check Dark-types like the aforementioned Scrafty, but it also provides Sticky Web support. Additionally, Silvally-Ghost can act as a spinblocker against the likes of Tsareena and Claydol and use either of them as setup fodder. Fighting-types like Poliwrath and Hitmontop can pressure defensive checks to Silvally-Ghost such as Miltank, Scrafty, and Regirock, especially when safely brought in with U-turn.

Silvally-Poison.overview: Silvally-Poison is primarily a niche breaker, but can also be a Defogger. Its typing works decently in a tier with prevalent Fairy-, Grass-, and Fighting-types such as Ribombee, Tsareena, and Scrafty, respectively. Silvally-Poison's Toxic immunity makes it a potent threat against passive teams, as it can freely setup on clerics such as Audino and Aromatisse and still have coverage for checks like Togedemaru. Being able to fit Grass Pledge comfortably to counter Quagsire distinguishes it from other Silvally formes. However, Silvally-Poison often is outperformed as a breaker by other Silvally formes with more intimidating offensive typings like Silvally-Ghost and Silvally-Fairy. As a Defogger, Silvally-Poison fits nicely on bulkier teams as a Knock Off and Toxic Spikes absorber; even so, Silvally-Steel and Silvally-Water are generally easier to fit onto teams because they are not as commonly checked by defensive staples like Weezing and Togedemaru.

sets.name: Work Up
sets.description: Silvally-Poison fits nicely on bulky offense and balance teams in need of a stallbreaker. It is great at dismantling bulky teams through Work Up. Multi-Attack allows it to muscle through specially defensive Pokemon like Articuno and Audino. Flamethrower nails Steel-types like Togedemaru and Silvally-Steel. Grass Pledge is useful for targeting Quagsire and Palossand. Surf, as an alternative to Grass Pledge, does more damage to Aggron in exchange for not breaking Quagsire. Ferroseed is a good partner for Silvally-Poison by providing Spikes support. They compliment each other defensively as well, as Ferroseed can switch into Psychic-types like Mesprit and Silvally-Poison can switch into Fighting-types like Scrafty. Jellicent is also a solid fit for dealing with opposing Fighting-types and spreading burns for easier setup later. Other partners such as Galvantula and Whimsicott can lure in defensive Pokemon like Audino for Silvally-Poison to set (add space) up on. Charizard benefits from Silvally-Poison tanking Knock Off and pressuring common defensive cores. In return, Charizard offers more immediate power and can wear down shared checks like Gigalith.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description: Defogger Silvally-Poison checks common Pokemon like Tsareena and makes for decent hazard removal on bulkier teams. The Speed investment allows Silvally-Poison to Defog before Qwilish can Taunt it. Poison-type Multi-Attack pressures common threats like Silvally-Fairy. Flamethrower hits Steel-types like Alolan Sandslash and Ferroseed super effectively. U-turn allows Silvally-Poison to pivot without triggering Competitive Galarian Articuno. Silvally-Poison is worn down fast by entry hazards when removing them, so clerics like Aromatisse and Audino are valuable partners. Tangela and Gourgeist check common Ground-types that Silvally-Poison is vulnerable against such as Sandaconda. Unaware Quagsire nullifies the various setup sweepers in the tier and reciprocally benefits from Silvally-Poison dealing with Grass-types.

Silvally-Rock.overview: The following analysis was written in a prior iteration of the PU metagame and as a result does not accurately reflect the current state of the tier, where Silvally-Rock is considered outclassed and not worth using. This page will be updated later to reflect this.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Silvally-Rock finds a solid niche in PU as a Swords Dance sweeper, obtaining setup opportunities against common foes such as Mr. Rime and Unfezant. Swords Dance bolsters Silvally-Rock's attacking prowess, letting it break through slower foes such as Appletun and Dusknoir. U-turn provides valuable utility and allows Silvally-Rock to pivot away from checks such as Sandslash and Throh. Alternatively, Flame Charge turns Silvally-Rock into a better late-game cleaner, boosting its Speed stat, letting it hit Klinklang, and enabling it to outspeed offensive checks such as Galarian Rapidash and Alolan Dugtrio and Choice Scarf users such as Drednaw and Golduck. Ice Beam serves as coverage for Ground-types such as Stunfisk and Sandslash. Psychic Fangs is a notable mention that allows Silvally-Rock to better break through Fighting-types like Throh and Falinks. Swords Dance Silvally-Rock is often found on offensive builds that appreciate its ability to fire off strong Multi-Attacks, keep offensive momentum with U-turn, and potentially clean late-game. If running Flame Charge over U-turn, Silvally-Rock should be preserved until late-game when its checks have been weakened or removed and it can set up and sweep. Partners such as Unfezant and Morpeko weaken physical walls such as Stunfisk and Sandslash, helping facilitate a late-game sweep. Pairing Silvally-Rock with special wallbreakers such as Appletun, Nasty Plot Gourgeist, and Mr. Rime can be beneficial, as they can take advantage of the aforementioned physical walls and defensive Throh; Eject Pack Appletun can also provide more setup opportunities by bringing Silvally-Rock in on special walls such as Type: Null and Lickilicky. Stunfisk and Sandslash also make for good partners, providing checks to Steel-types such as Klinklang and Mawile and setting up entry hazards. Checks to Fighting-types such as Galarian Rapidash, Mr. Rime, and Unfezant are also appreciated, with the former two also providing Healing Wish support.

sets.name: Offensive Defog
sets.description: Silvally-Rock finds a slight niche in PU as an offensive Defog user, thanks to its strong Multi-Attack that gives it good matchups against common foes such as Mr. Rime, Unfezant, and Drifblim. Ice Beam targets Ground-types such as Stunfisk and Sandslash, while Flamethrower punishes switch-ins from Steel-types such as Klinklang and Mawile, letting Silvally-Rock utilize Defog against Mawile. U-turn establishes offensive momentum, allowing Silvally-Rock to pivot away from and accrue residual damage on checks such as Sandslash and Throh. This Silvally-Rock set fits on balance and bulky offense builds that appreciate its offensive capabilities and good utility in Defog and U-turn. Grass-types such as Appletun, Gourgeist, and Lilligant appreciate Silvally-Rock checking Fire- and Ice-types such as Flareon and Mr. Rime, as well as Flying-types like Unfezant and Drifblim. In return, they can threaten Water- and Ground-types such as Golduck, Stunfisk, and Sandslash. Lilligant is a notable partner, able to capitalize on switches that Silvally-Rock forces to set up with Quiver Dance or heal up Silvally-Rock with Healing Wish, depending on its set. Setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Galarian Rapidash and Calm Mind Musharna benefit from Silvally-Rock clearing entry hazards and improving their longevity; in return, they can remove Fighting-types such as Throh and Falinks that trouble Silvally-Rock. Wallbreakers such as Mr. Rime and Beheeyem appreciate Silvally-Rock luring in physical walls such as Stunfisk and Sandslash to wreak havoc. Pokemon such as Klinklang and Drifblim can also lure in the aformentioned physical walls and cripple them with Toxic, allowing Silvally-Rock to potentially get off a Defog against them.

Silvally-Water.overview: Often appearing on balance teams, Silvally-Water is a decent Defogger that is able to threaten common Stealth Rock setters such as Sandaconda and Regirock. It also possesses decent defensive utility and can easily pivot into its teammates with Parting Shot or U-turn. As a result of its weaknesses to Grass- and Electric-type moves, Silvally-Water is threatened by Pokemon such as Tsareena and Togedemaru. Silvally-Water also faces competition from Whimsicott and Charizard as an entry hazard remover. Silvally-Water can be worn down easily and struggles to consistently check foes such as Charizard. Furthermore, it is outclassed as a bulky Water-type by Pokemon such as Jellicent and Lanturn due to the former possessing recovery and the latter having an Electric immunity.

sets.name: Defensive Defog
sets.description: Silvally-Water's teammates appreciate its ability to remove entry hazards and bring them in safely with Parting Shot or U-turn; its ability to lure foes such as Tsareena benefits Pokemon such as Magmortar, and it can also function as a slow pivot for frail partners such as Heavy-Duty Boots Archeops. Surf hits foes such as Sandaconda and Charizard super effectively. Ice Beam prevents foes such as offensive Whimsicott and Trevenant from switching into Silvally-Water. Thunderbolt can be used over Ice Beam, as it deters switch-ins from foes like Wishiwashi and Kabutops. Toxic is also an option to defeat bulky Water-types such as Jellicent and Lanturn. The EV spread makes Silvally-Water as bulky as possible while letting it outspeed foes such as Tsareena and Adamant Kabutops. Aromatisse is an extremely valuable teammate for Silvally-Water, as it is able to switch in comfortably on foes such Scrafty, which would otherwise use Silvally-Water as setup fodder, and provide Wish and cleric support. Silvally-Water appreciates Grass-type teammates such as Ferroseed, as they can switch into Electric-types such as Togedemaru and Lanturn for it. In return, Silvally-Water can defeat Fire-types such as Charizard and Centiskorch. Charizard is able to handle Grass-types such as Tangela and Gourgeist-S while benefitting from Silvally-Water's ability to deal with Rock-types such as Regirock.

Togedemaru.overview: Togedemaru stands out as one of the best Choice Scarf users in the tier thanks to its solid Speed tier, great offensive and defensive typing that allows it to check Pokemon such as Archeops and Whimsicott, ability to gain momentum through U-turn, and good abilities. Its unique defensive typing and access to recovery in Wish also makes Togedemaru a useful special wall for taking on certain difficult threats such as Ribombee and Vikavolt. However, despite its excellent set of resistances, its mediocre bulk and an unreliable recovery move limits Togedemaru's ability to directly switch into threats. Sitting at base 96 Speed, it is one of the fastest Choice Scarf users and can outspeed boosted setup sweepers like Modest Ludicolo and Silvally-Fairy. However, Togedemaru fails to OHKO many of these Pokemon due to its only average Attack stat and coverage options. Togedemaru faces strong competition as a specially defensive Steel-type from Aggron and Galarian Stunfisk, who can set up Stealth Rock, and as a Wish passer from Aromatisse due to its much higher HP stat.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Toxic is useful for crippling switch-ins like Palossand and Vikavolt rather than merely pivoting out with U-turn, while Encore is more effective at annoying bulky setup sweepers such as Scrafty. Lightning Rod is useful for pivoting into Volt Switch users such as Rotom and Vikavolt, but the chip damage from Iron Barbs is preferred if there is already an Electric-immune Pokemon on the team. Iron Barbs also helps defeat opposing Choice Scarf Togedemaru. While Togedemaru can be used throughout the match to tank some resisted hits, it is best brought in as a revenge killer or through slow pivots such as Lanturn and Uxie, which form a VoltTurn core with it. Due to Togedemaru's poor damage output, it appreciates entry hazards from the likes of Gigalith and Froslass to help wear down its foes. Wallbreakers such as Whimsicott and Magmortar can also help wear down the opposing team so Togedemaru can potentially clean late-game, and they also serve as checks for threats to Togedemaru such as Palossand and Vikavolt, respectively.

sets.name: Wish Passer
sets.description: Iron Head is Togedemaru's attacking move of choice because it better threatens Pokemon Togedemaru is aiming to check such as Frosmoth and Whimsicott and does not leave Togedemaru unable to hit Ground-types. U-turn allows Togedemaru to slightly circumvent its passivity by pivoting on predicted switches, but Toxic cripples many Pokemon that Togedemaru cannot do much damage to such as Vikavolt. Heavy-Duty Boots significantly decreases Togedemaru's weakness to Spikes, Leftovers helps make it slightly less reliant on Wish, and Rocky Helmet in tandem with Iron Barbs allows Togedemaru to punish a wide variety of contact attackers. However, Lightning Rod is preferred to stop Volt Switch users such as Vikavolt and Rotom. 8 Speed EVs allow Togedemaru to outspeed Adamant Centiskorch and Modest Frosmoth. Togedemaru can support many teammates lacking recovery with Wish, such as Weezing and Uxie, both of which also help against the Fighting-and Ground-types that threaten Togedemaru. Setup sweepers that can take advantage of Fighting- and Ground-types, such as Nasty Plot Mesprit and Quiver Dance Ribombee, appreciate being brought in through Togedemaru's U-turn.

Thwackey.overview: While there are better Grass-types in the tier such as Whimsicott and Trevenant, Thwackey primarily stands out with Grassy Surge, letting it support setup sweepers like Hitmonlee and making it a decent wallbreaker and revenge killer. It has limited coverage, but it can make up for that with Grassy Glide, raw strength behind its STAB Wood Hammer, and the utility of Knock Off and U-turn. However, the tier has a fair amount of Grass-resistant Pokemon that can outspeed and threaten Thwackey such as Charizard and Whimsicott. Thwackey also competes with Tsareena, which has better bulk, superior coverage, more natural strength, and access to Rapid Spin.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band allows Thwackey to maximize its power combined with Grassy Terrain. Knock Off is able to cripple common Grass-resistant Pokemon such as Charizard and Tangela. U-turn allows Thwackey to pivot on Grass-resistant that are not heavily bothered by Knock Off such as Weezing and Silvally-Poison. Grassy Surge allows Thwackey to support setup sweepers such as Grassy Seed Hitmonlee and Swoobat. Ribombee is able to form a U-turn core with Thwackey and switch it in against bulky Water-types like Lanturn. Ribombee also appreciates Thwackey weakening Steel-types. Together, they can overwhelm Grass-resistant Pokemon like Weezing and Togedemaru. Uxie and Silvally-Fairy are reliable pivots that can switch in Thwackey to safely set Grassy Terrain again or sweepers like Hitmonlee and Thievul to set up. With Grassy Terrain, Aggron appreciates the weakened Earthquake damage and passive recovery.

Coalossal.overview: While undoubtedly niche, Coalossal possesses a few attributes to stand out among other Rock-types. Unlike other entry hazard removers such as Charizard and Silvally-Fairy, it can set hazards, and it's sturdier then both. Coalossal's Fire typing gives it an easier time dealing with Bug- and Fairy-types, such as Ribombee and Whimsicott, than other Rock-types. Additionally, Flame Body lets it punish reckless U-turn users like Ninjask and other physical attackers. However, because of its common 4x weaknesses in Water and Ground, Coalossal is incredibly vulnerable to Pokemon like Quagsire, Sandaconda, and Jellicent. Additionally, many of the Pokemon it wishes to check, such as Charizard, Scyther, and Centiskorch, have coverage moves to chunk it or can cripple it with Knock Off for the latter two, or Toxic for Charizard. For these reasons, Coalossal can only fit into teams that require its specific niches, facing heavy competition from the likes of Gigalith, Regirock, and Aggron, which are all less passive than Coalossal and can hold Leftovers due to not needing Heavy-Duty Boots. Furthermore, Aggron's Steel typing lets it better check Psychic-types.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Coalossal can opt for Spikes if used with another Stealth Rock setter. Rapid Spin is its claim to fame over other Rock-types. Defensive Jellicent is an ideal partner for Coalossal, as it checks Pokemon such as Poliwrath and Galarian Stunfisk for it. Ferroseed and Druddigon can stack entry hazards with Coalossal and provide extra utility, like both spreading paralysis, Ferroseed bringing Knock Off, and Druddigon checking Ground- and Fighting-types. As Coalossal appreciates checks to Water-, Ground-, and Fighting-types, like Silvally-Water, Palossand, and Gallade, Pokemon such as Whimsicott and Weezing make for good partners. Meanwhile, wallbreakers like Dragon Dance Scrafty and Trevenant appreciate hazard support from Coalossal and have good type synergy with it, as Coalossal checks the Fairy-, Fire-, and Flying-types that check Scrafty and Trevenant, while the latter checks both Water- and Ground-types for Coalossal.

Flapple.overview: Flapple carves a niche for itself in PU as a brutally strong wallbreaker. With its Hustle-boosted attacks, Flapple can OHKO or 2HKO most Pokemon with its sheer strength while also dropping their Defense with Grav Apple, making it easier for a teammate to pick them off. Flapple's typing also allows it to take advantage of multiple defensive Pokemon such as Sandaconda and non-Ice Beam Lanturn. However, Flapple sports a detrimental 4x weakness to Ice as well as weaknesses to common types such as Flying, Bug, and Fairy. Additionally, its poor bulk makes Flapple unable to take many hits, and its middling Speed tier causes Flapple to pale in comparison to other offensive threats such as Charizard and Silvally formes. Hustle is also a double-edged sword for Flapple; while it does increase Flapple's potency as a wallbreaker, it also decreases accuracy by a fair amount, making it possible for Flapple to miss an attack and either be severely damaged or outright KOed. Flapple faces stiff competition from Tsareena as a Grass-type and Life Orb Gallade as a wallbreaker, as both Pokemon sport better bulk and Speed tiers while also offering more utility to a team.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: U-turn is used to gain momentum on predicted switches. Sucker Punch allows Flapple to pick off faster threats such as Galarian Articuno and Froslass. Grav Apple's guaranteed Defense drop also makes it easier to take out weakened Pokemon with Sucker Punch. If running Thwackey alongside Flapple, Grassy Glide is the preferred priority move. While Choice Band is preferred to maximize Flapple's wallbreaking power, Life Orb can be used to switch moves, albeit at the cost of reducing Flapple's longevity. Miracle Seed is an option to bluff Choice Band, although the loss of power on other attacks is noticeable. Steel-types such as Aggron and Togedemaru are able to force out Ice- and Fairy-types like Frosmoth and Ribombee, which Flapple cannot handle on its own, with Togedemaru also forming a U-turn core with Flapple. Fire-types like Charizard and Centiskorch can check Steel-types while providing valuable support with Toxic and Knock Off, respectively. As many of Flapple's checks are easily worn down, it greatly enjoys Spikes and Toxic Spikes support from the likes of Froslass and Weezing. Thwackey can offer Grassy Terrain support for Flapple, powering up Grav Apple even further and turning Grassy Glide into a reliable, STAB priority move. Finally, Pokemon that Flapple can bring in via U-turn, such as Lycanroc and Archeops, are recommended partners.

Sandaconda.overview: Sandaconda is able to serve as a consistent Stealth Rock user and Electric-immune Pokemon with its natural bulk and Shed Skin. With Shed Skin and Rest, Sandaconda is able to remain healthy throughout the game to check Pokemon like Gigalith, Aggron, and Togedemaru. Sandaconda also provides speed control with Glare, making it less easy to take advantage of. Sandaconda's decent Speed and Attack mean it can even commit to a Coil set, although its typing and poor Special Defense leaves it forced out by tier staples like Whimsicott. However, Sandaconda still faces competition from Palossand as a Stealth Rock user and Electric-immune Pokemon, as it has more consistent recovery and better bulk. Shed Skin is also not consistent, making it unsafe to be overly dependent on Rest.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description: Sandaconda is able to cripple Pokemon it cannot touch with Earthquake like Mesprit and Archeops with Glare. Rest is able to keep Sandaconda healthy and is more reliable in combination with Shed Skin. Rocky Helmet allows Sandaconda to wear down Pokemon such as Togedemaru. Leftovers gives Sandaconda more sustainability, but it is often switching into Knock Off from Pokemon like Absol anyway. The Speed investment allows Sandaconda to outspeed Adamant Aggron. Pokemon like Togedemaru and Lanturn are able to provide Wish and cleric support respectively so Sandaconda is less reliant on Shed Skin, and can sponge special attacks from Pokemon such as Ribombee and Charizard. In return, Sandaconda can switch into strong physical attackers like Lycanroc and Archeops. Wallbreakers such as Gallade and Magmortar are able to capitalize on Sandaconda spreading paralysis. Sandaconda can run Stone Edge over Glare to hit Flying-types like Archeops at the cost of providing less support.

sets.name: Defensive Coil
sets.description: With Coil, recovery, and the ability to expel status conditions with Shed Skin, Sandaconda becomes a dangerous threat late-game. Ground- and Rock-type moves hit the entire tier for neutral coverage. Stone Edge has more power and a higher critical hit chance but low PP, while Rock Slide has less power but higher PP, which is useful in longer games where the opponent can stall out Stone Edge PP. The Speed investment allows Sandaconda to move before Adamant Aggron, with the remainder of its EVs allocated to its special bulk. Some physical bulk could be useful to ease setup against Pokemon like Silvally formes and Scrafty. Grass- and Water-types such as Whimsicott and Wishiwashi prevent Sandaconda from setting up, so teammates that can switch into and threaten such foes are crucial to Sandaconda's success. Ferroseed has the bulk and typing to handle a majority of offensive Grass- and Water-types, and can take advantage of their presence as an opportunity to lay entry hazards. Charizard and Gourgeist-S similarly threaten the Grass- and Water-types that Sandaconda dislikes. These teammates also appreciate Sandaconda turning Archeops and Togedemaru into setup fodder late game, as they are forced out by both of them. Grass-type breakers like Trevenant and Gourgeist-S can bait in and wear down opposing Ground-type checks like Tangela and Claydol, while also forcing out Water-types like Poliwrath and Quagsire. Stealth Rock setters such as Gigalith and Miltank can allow Sandaconda to run Coil by filling in the role of a Stealth Rock user. In return, Sandaconda can switch into threatening Fighting-type foes like Scrafty, especially with the aforementioned physical bulk investment option.

Centiskorch.overview: Centiskorch makes for a great wallbreaker thanks to its fantastic movepool and great Attack, allowing it to beat most physically defensive walls and Fire-resistant Pokemon like Palossand, Gigalith, and Jellicent. Its ability Flash Fire, decent special bulk, and typing allow it to switch into threats like Magmortar and Ribombee, although its lack of recovery means it can't do so very often. However, Centiskorch's mediocre defensive typing, Speed, and Defense leave it susceptible to many faster threats like Absol, Archeops, and Basculin, which also makes it harder to get it in the field safely.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Fire Lash makes Centiskorch harder to switch into, and it allows Centiskorch to get past defensive behemoths like Weezing and Jellicent more easily. Power Whip hits Ground-, Rock-, and Water-types, and Knock Off allows Centiskorch to cripple foes reliant on their items. Due to its poor physical bulk, typing, and Speed, Centiskorch greatly appreciates teammates capable of bringing it in safely; Archeops, Togedemaru, and Ribombee are great examples, as they all appreciate it weakening down their answers like Gigalith. Basculin is another great example, as it enjoys Centiskorch softening up Jellicent. Answers to Flying-, Rock-, and Water-types like Charizard, Aggron, and Kabutops are greatly appreciated, as Centiskorch often finds itself forced out by them. This makes Regirock and Ferroseed great partners as they can also support it with their Stealth Rock, giving it an easier time wallbreaking.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
Due to its ability to boost its stats with Bulk Up as well as its access to semi-reliable recovery in Drain Punch, Grapploct can function as a solid wincon on balance teams while also being able to check physical attackers such as Morpeko. Brutal Swing allows Grapploct to hit Psychic- and Ghost-types such as Musharna and Gourgeist, whereas Sucker Punch gives it the ability to hit faster Pokemon such as Boltund as well as deal with offensive teams in general. The given HP and Defense investment lets Grapploct avoid the 2HKO from Life Orb Drednaw's Liquidation after Stealth Rock, while the Special Defense EVs let it take Modest Choice Specs Glaceon's Ice Beam after Stealth Rock.

Psychic-types such as Mr. Rime, Beheeyem, and Galarian Rapidash can handle Poison-types like Mareanie for Grapploct, while they in turn appreciate Grapploct's ability to handle Dark-types like Morpeko. Morpeko in turn aids Grapploct in dealing with Ghost- and Psychic-types, which Grapploct can struggle against while Beheeyem can provide slow momentum for Grapploct with Teleport. Entry hazard support from Pokemon such as Roselia and Stunfisk further aid Grapploct in wearing down foes. Fairy-types such as Galarian Rapidash and Shiinotic are difficult for Grapploct to deal with as well, so Pokemon such as Roselia, Drednaw, Mawile, and Flareon make for decent partners. Mawile and Pawniard also provide Knock Off support to weaken bulkier Pokemon such as Mareanie that can be problematic for Grapploct to handle. Healing Wish support from Pokemon such as Mr. Mime and Galarian Rapidash can provide Grapploct with a second chance to sweep.

Runerigus.overview: Runerigus is able to provide a fair amount of utility with its typing and ability to spread both status and entry hazards. It has the natural Defense to withstand strong attacks from Pokemon like Lycanroc and various Silvally formes. Runerigus is also capable of being a setup sweeper to become less passive and take advantage of Pokemon like Toxic Regirock expecting to just wear it down. However, its typing leaves it vulnerable to common wallbreakers like Tsareena and Froslass. It also faces heavy competition from Palossand, which has similar defensive qualities and reliable recovery, although it lacks Toxic Spikes and is generally more one-dimensional. Cofagrigus rivals Runerigus as a bulky setup sweeper with its typing and is better at keeping up Toxic Spikes, as it can safely spinblock Tsareena. However, Runerigus is able to fit Amnesia more easily.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Runerigus's bulk gives it a fair amount of opportunities to set up entry hazards against Pokemon like Archeops and Togedemaru. Leftovers provides passive recovery, while Colbur Berry lets Runerigus switch into Knock Off users like Gallade and Sawk comfortably. Earthquake hits Magmortar and Charizard using Roost, but Body Press can be used for more damage against switch-ins like Tsareena and Scrafty while still hitting typical Earthquake targets like Regirock and Gigalith. Will-O-Wisp cripples Archeops and deters Swords Dance Silvally formes. Toxic Spikes lets Runerigus spread more status and support setup sweepers like Charizard and Gallade. Poltergeist is an alternative to hit Pokemon like Whimsicott and Ribombee as well as opposing Ghost-types like Haunter. Rest gives Runerigus some form of recovery and pairs nicely with clerics like Aromatisse and Lanturn that can reliably beat special attackers such as Charizard and Magmortar that Runerigus struggles against. Aromatisse can also deal with Scrafty and provides Wish support for it.

sets.name: Bulky Setup Sweeper
sets.description: Runerigus is able to further push its defensive capabilities with Iron Defense and Amnesia to become a durable setup sweeper. Full Defense investment maximizes Body Press's power, but a specially defensive spread can be used to more comfortably boost against Galvantula and Charizard. Rest is Runerigus's only means of recovery and prevents it from being worn down by Toxic. Body Press allows it to capitalize on Iron Defense further and hit extremely hard. Leftovers provides passive recovery to lessen the need to use Rest, but Chesto Berry can be used for a free Rest and to have an easier time snowballing. Runerigus is completely walled by opposing Ghost-types like Froslass and Haunter with this set, so it benefits from Dark-types like Scrafty and Absol to pressure them. Weezing can spread burns to give Runerigus more setup opportunities and use Toxic Spikes to prevent Ghost-types like Palossand and Gourgeist from stalling it out. Fighting-types like Hitmontop and Gallade can check opposing Dark- and Ice-types like Absol and Arctovish and draw in bulky Pokemon like Quagsire and Sandaconda that Runerigus can use as setup fodder. Runerigus is also vulnerable to Pokemon such as Tsareena and Choice Specs Whimsicott that can break past it before it can boost high enough, so offensive checks to them like Charizard and Silvally-Steel are appreciated.

Frosmoth.overview: Despite competition from Ribombee, with its superior typing and speed, as a Bug-type sweeper, Frosmoth makes for a niche yet threatening setup sweeper thanks to Quiver Dance and potent offensive coverage. Ice Scales also gives it many setup opportunities against special attackers such as Mesprit and Whimsicott, which differentiates it from Ribombee. Frosmoth's underwhelming Speed and physical bulk, mediocre defensive typing, and inability to hit Steel-types for significant damage render it easy to revenge kill and a liability in certain matchups.

sets.name: Quiver Dance
sets.description: Substitute allows Frosmoth to avoid status conditions from Pokemon like Lanturn and Palossand while making it harder to revenge kill. Giga Drain grants Frosmoth with recovery and targets Water-types like Jellicent, as well as dealing super effective damage to Rock-types like Regirock and Gigalith. Frosmoth greatly appreciates partners that can wear down the Steel-types it struggles to get past; Choice Specs Whimsicott and Mesprit make for great options, and they can both also cripple Pokemon like specially defensive Aggron and Togedemaru by using Switcheroo and Trick, respectively. Due to its lackluster Speed tier, Frosmoth finds itself easily revenge killed by threats like Choice Scarf Togedemaru; teammates like Silvally-Ghost and Coil Sandaconda can use the aforementioned threats that Frosmoth invites in as setup fodder. Charizard can wear down Pokemon like Gigalith with Toxic and can threaten Steel-types like defensive Togedemaru.

sets.name: Belly Drum
sets.description:
Eiscue's unique Ability in Ice Face and access to Belly Drum make it a threatening, albeit matchup dependent, late-game sweeper. Reversal is an 80-Base Power attack after Eiscue uses Substitute and Belly Drum, providing great neutral coverage alongside Eiscue's Ice STAB and letting it take down Steel-type Pokemon it otherwise couldn't, such as Mawile, Pawniard, and Klang, as well as Lapras. Zen Headbutt sacrifices hitting those target in order to cover Mareanie, which otherwise walls Eiscue. Liquidation is a niche option that deals more damage to the aforementioned targets before Eiscue is set up. Substitute provides Eiscue with protection from status and revenge killing, and lets it activate its Salac Berry after using Belly Drum, outspeeding most of the unboosted metagame even if Ice Face hasn't been activated and outrunning even the fastest boosted Pokemon, like Choice Scarf Manectric and Quick Feet Galarian Linoone, if it has been activated. Belly Drum brings Eiscue's otherwise mediocre Attack stat to ridiculous levels, making it vital to sweeping. A Jolly nature with maximum Speed investment is used to let Eiscue outspeed fast Pokemon like Leafeon and Silvally at +1 if Ice Face isn't activated.

Eiscue fits best on offensive teams that can break through its defensive answers. If Eiscue isn't running Zen Headbutt, teammates that can take on Mareanie are absolutely vital. Good examples of these teammates include Electric-type Pokemon like Manectric and Raichu and Psychic-type Pokemon like Mr. Mime, Musharna, and Mr. Rime, the latter of which can also remove entry hazards. Roselia can use Spikes or Toxic Spikes to help wear down the opponent's defensive backbone, check Water-types, put opposing Pokemon to sleep to provide Eiscue with more setup opportunities, and removes Toxic Spikes, which would otherwise shut Eiscue down. If Eiscue isn't running Reversal, teammates that can take on Steel-types are important. Falinks and Hitmontop are good at pressuring foes like Mawile, Klang, and Pawniard offensively, with Falinks fitting very well on hyper offense and Hitmontop offering hazard removal and reliable priority. The aforementioned Psychic-types are also great options for wearing down Steel-types, as most teams rely on those Pokemon to take them on, with Mr. Rime, Mr. Mime, and Musharna giving Eiscue a safe switch and a second chance at setting up via Healing Wish. Pivots such as the aforementioned Electric-type Pokemon, Silvally formes, and Drakloak can be useful for getting Eiscue on the field safely against Pokemon that it threatens, like Roselia, or that can't bypass Ice Face, as is the case for most physical attackers lacking Knock Off. Stonjourner makes for a strong lead option on offense that can provide Stealth Rock support and threaten several of Eiscue's answers with Earthquake. Other setup sweepers, like Fraxure, Pawniard, and the previously mentioned Falinks and Raichu, are effective at softening the opponent's defensive backbone for Eiscue. Wallbreakers like Swords Dance Mawile, Throh, and Choice Band Fraxure are effective teammates for the same purpose, with the former two being able to use Knock Off on sturdy answers to Eiscue, like Mareanie and Klang, that rely on their Eviolite to function effectively.
